DOC.HEAD: Eleventh Depression Disperses While No. 12 Loiters in Open Atlantic
DOC.TEXT: The season's 11th tropical depression dissipated in the mid-Atlantic on Sunday while No. 12 lingered about 1,000 miles to the west, forecasters said. Sunday evening, the season's 11th tropical depression lost its center at latitude 19.7 north, longitude 52.7 west, about 700 miles east-northeast of the Leeward Islands. By 10:30 p.m., forecasters at the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Cables located tropical depression No. 12 at latitude 19.3 north, longitude 34.2 west, or about 700 miles west-northwest of the Cape Verde Islands off the western shoulder of Africa. It was drifting west-northwest near 4 mph with top sustained winds of 35 mph, and was expected to maintain its speed and strength while gradually turning to the northwest by Monday night. Tropical depressions become tropical storms if their maximum sustained winds top 39 mph. Storms become hurricanes if the winds top 74 mph. September is usually the most active month for the Atlantic hurricane season, which lasts from June 1 to Nov. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Jesse Jackson Says He Hopes To Mediate Mohawk Standoff
DOC.TEXT: Civil rights activist Jesse Jackson said Sunday that he hoped to mediate a solution to the standoff between police and Mohawk Indians in Oka. ``Hopefully, through dialogue and through the interviewing process the tensions will ease and the bloodshed will stop,'' he told reporters after arriving in Montreal. ``And there will be some rational resolution to this conflict.'' Jackson said he's already spoken to Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa about his efforts to resolve the crisis. ``The problem that develops in standoffs is that people harden their positions,'' he said. ``And when talking becomes impossible, violence becomes inevitable.'' Army spokesman Maj. John Paul MacDonald said Jackson will be denied access to the Kahnesatake treatment center, where about 50 Mohawk women, children and men have been encircled by soldiers for the last three weeks. ``As with everyone else who has requested to come into the perimeter but really has no business being there, he will be refused as well,'' MacDonald said. The 74-day standoff began over plans to sell property in the town of Oka that the Mohawks claim is ancestral land. Quebec provincial police stormed an Indian roadblock in Oka on July 11 and Cpl. Marcel Lemay was killed in the ensuing gun battle. It has not been determined who was responsible for his death.

DOC.HEAD: Sen. Mitchell Willing to Consider Dole Budget Compromise
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th graf, ``His remarks xxx to update with 4-hour session completed with no indication of progress; STANDS FOR AMS
DOC.TEXT: Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell said Sunday that Democrats are willing to consider a Republican idea for unsnarling stalled budget talks by placing a capital gains tax cut into a separate package. Mitchell's comment was the first indication that Democrats might be willing to explore the suggestion, which Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., made Thursday. The fight over whether to slash the capital gains tax rate is perhaps the major hurdle remaining for the two sides to complete a five-year, $500 billion deficit-reduction package. ``We'd be prepared to consider it, to work, to see precisely what he has in mind, and to come up with some way to get this thing done,'' said Mitchell, D-Maine, on CBS's ``Face the Nation.'' His remarks came before eight budget bargainers from the Bush administration and Congress held a four-hour, closed-door evening session in the Capitol. There was no indication what, if any, progress was made by the group, which has met four other times since last Tuesday in an effort to end a yearlong budget stalemate. Another meeting was scheduled for Monday. Meanwhile, President Bush was reported to have expressed optimism about a budget agreement during a conversation with Maryland Gov. William Donald Schaefer. Schaefer, who talked with the president at a Maryland golf course where he stopped for an 18-hole round en route back to the White House from Camp David, had told reporters beforehand how worried he was about the prospects of massive furloughs starting Oct. 1 if the White House and Congress fail to reach a budget agreement. Thousands of federal workers live in the Maryland suburbs of Washington and Baltimore, where Social Security's headquarters is located. After speaking with Bush, Schaefer said he told the president, ``I'm very worried.'' He said the president replied ``I think we'll have a deal.'' ``He was not pessimistic. He was very optimistic,'' the governor told reporters. Dole has suggested that the negotiators write two measures. One would contain tax increases and spending cuts. The second bill would contain what he on the same program called ``all the goodies.'' These would include the capital gains tax reduction, which Bush wants; a more expensive child care program, favored by Democrats; and tax breaks for the poor and for businesses. The measure - which could cost $50 billion or $60 billion - would have to be paid for by additional taxes or spending reductions. ``We ought to stop dancing around capital gains, face up to it, get it resolved and get this package put to bed,'' Dole said. Dole broke somewhat with his GOP colleagues by emphasizing the importance the capital gains dispute holds in clearing the way for a deal. Other Republicans have argued that differences over spending cuts and the types of taxes to be raised are just as important in finishing the negotiations. ``Right now the big hurdle is capital gains,'' Dole said. Dole seemed to express pique at the pace of negotiations favored by White House budget bargainers. ``We shouldn't be in too much of a rush,'' he said White House officials have told him. ``Well, I don't know what else they've got to do this year, but I've got a lot of things I'd like to do.'' The delay, he said, could be strategically costly. ``We're losing votes every day, in my view, in the House and the Senate by not getting it done,'' he said. It is unclear whether Dole's suggestion to create two packages will ever become a formal GOP offer at the budget talks. Some White House officials, including Chief of Staff John Sununu, have vehemently opposed the idea. At a news conference Friday, Bush failed to endorse it, but did not rule it out, either. The full impact of the idea is also uncertain because of an unusual voting procedure Dole has suggested. Under his plan, the two measures would be voted on separately. But if the ``goodies'' package were to be defeated, then the deficit-reduction measure would be considered rejected as well, even if it was approved on an earlier vote. The proposal raises yet another question: how would the capital gains tax reduction and other ``goodies'' be paid for? Budget bargainers have had a hard enough time coming up with $500 billion worth of savings, let alone having to find another $50 billion or $60 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Wrenching Goodbyes: Wives Who Fled Middle East Remain Hostages at Home
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rande in 8th graf and Anderton in 13th graf are cq.
DOC.TEXT: As food grew scarce and Iraqi soldiers more entrenched, Ruthie and her husband made the decision: She and their three young children could not remain in Kuwait. ``I don't like to talk this way in front of the kids, but here are my thoughts: It feels like I left him there to die,'' said Ruthie Al-Qallef, a Memphis, Tenn., native. ``l feel like I deserted him.'' She and hundreds of other American wives and children who fled the Middle East remain trapped by visions of loved ones left behind. ``Leaving him was the hardest thing I've ever done,'' said Mrs. Al-Qallef, whose husband of 10 years is a Kuwaiti military officer. ``His face scared me more than the whole six weeks we spent in hiding.'' Her husband's eyes were glazed, his expression frozen. His silence didn't add to the tension, she said. It was the tension: ``He didn't know how to say goodbye.'' Separated families were the result of Saddam Hussein's order that foreign men not be allowed to leave after his invasion of Kuwait in early August. Many are being used as shields against attack. An estimated 930 Americans remain in Kuwait and 170 in Iraq, the State Department says. At the time of the invasion, about 3,500 U.S. citizens were in either Iraq or Kuwait. Rande Vallekoop said goodbye to her husband, Laurens, soon after sunrise on Aug. 25. Bolstered by a night of shared whispers and prayers, the American woman avoided tears when she and the couple's two young daughters left her husband behind at the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad. ``I cried when I got to Turkey,'' said Mrs. Vallekoop, who returned home to relatives in Minneapolis. ``The people that met us at the border just kind of took us into their arms. It was so difficult knowing he was still in there.'' Mrs. Vallekoop and her husband, an employee at the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, were separated by Iraqi authorities after fleeing Kuwait. ``We were notified that only the women and children would be allowed to leave,'' Mrs. Vallekoop, 30, said recently. ``It was totally heart-wrenching.'' She has been able to speak periodically with her husband, who remains stranded but able to communicate with her from the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad. Bonnie Anderton hasn't had any word since parting with her husband, Richard, an engineer. The image of him cooped up at the besieged embassy in Kuwait is all she has to go on. And the picture isn't pretty. By the time Mrs. Anderton and her 10-year-old daughter left in August, embassy staff members had already begun draining the swimming pool for drinking water. ``The food was spoiling ... and the Iraqi troops had completely surrounded us,'' Mrs. Anderton, 40, said from Larkspur, Colo. ``It's the sort of thing where you make up your mind and you can't even feel anything until later. Your first responsibility is to your children.'' At first, Kristine Knutson wasn't sure what was best for her children. From her kitchen window in Kuwait, the Minnesota native with four children under the age of 8 could hear bombs and see helicopters swarming overhead. Mrs. Knutson, who asked that her maiden name be used to protect her husband's identity, waited more than a month before finally deciding that the only route she could take was out of the Middle East. ``The windows at our house were covered. We couldn't answer the door or the telephone. The kids had to stay indoors ... and it was so hot,'' Mrs. Knutson said in a telephone interview last week from Minneapolis. ``You couldn't find chicken, eggs, bread. I heard the medical supplies were getting low, too,'' she said. ``I just kept thinking: `I have to get my children out of here.' I knew I had to leave my husband.'' Now she, like the other displaced mothers, is thinking about how to make ends meet. They are looking for jobs, getting their kids into school, pushing back frightening thoughts of their husbands for the sake of their kids. ``At night we all sleep together, the kids and me. They're wonderful, but so little. It's not like snuggling up against your big husband,'' said Mrs. Al-Qallef. ``I want my husband back.''

DOC.HEAD: Sioux Publisher Brings Insights, Questions to Harvard
DOC.TEXT: This is the world according to Tim Giago: -Ellis Island was a gateway for invaders. -Tourists who visit Pine Ridge Reservation, his homeland in South Dakota, are constantly deanding to see ``the real Indians.'' -At a powwow he witnessed in Oxford, Mass., participants dressed up in turkey feathers to improvise an Indian ritual they had never learned. ``There are so many misconceptions, it's going to take the rest of my life to get rid of them,'' said Giago, 55, an Oglala Sioux who is the founding publisher of the award-winning Lakota Times of Rapid City, S.D. Giago is taking a break from daily reporting on American Indians to spend a year as a Nieman fellow at Harvard University. ``I have only one mission,'' Giago said. ``I started a newspaper 10 years ago because the media in the United States are totally ignorant of who we are and what we are. If I relied on the mainstream press to do our story from our perspective, it will never happen.'' Since the first Nieman class of journalists in 1938, there have been 862 Niemans. Giago is the program's first American Indian print journalist. There was one other American Indian Nieman, in broadcasting. Fellows selected for the prestigious program spend a year at Harvard studying whatever they wish and meeting in seminars. This year's class has 22 journalists, half of them American. Giago said he hopes to enlighten his fellow scholars and the Harvard staff on the Indian perspective. ``What I see here even, it's almost as if people believe that to be Indian you're supposed to wear headdresses and live in a teepee,'' Giago said in a recent interview. ``We're locked in a certain time in history.'' As a 17-year-old Navy recruit during the Korean War, Giago was sent to California and put to work on a Navy newspaper. He later studied business and journalism at the University of Nevada and worked for newspapers in New Mexico and South Dakota. He became discouraged when editors said they didn't think he should cover Indian matters because he might be biased. Giago said he recognized that before getting the Indian viewpoint into the mainstream media, it would be necessary to satisfy the needs of the country's 1.4 million Native Americans. His newspaper has a circulation of 11,000 on 24 reservations in the Dakotas, Montana and Nebraska. ``Mine is a community newspaper that reports everything important to Indian people,'' he said. Indians often bring a different perspective to national events, he said. Take the melting pot that was celebrated recently with the opening of an immigration museum in New York Harbor at Ellis Island, where immigrants poured into this country in search of freedom and opportunity. ``Ellis Island doesn't mean a damn thing to the American Indian,'' Giago said. ``To us, it was another form of invasion.'' Giago said he wants to establish a network of Indian newspapers and expand the Lakota Times into a national publication. For two years after he founded his newspaper, the building was firebombed and its windows were shot out. A gunman blasted the windshield of his car after he wrote editorials critical of militant Indians. Giago said he has been enraged again and again by newspaper or TV coverage of Pine Ridge. Reporters catalog the problems of alcoholism, poverty, violence and unemployment but never dig deep enough to find the causes, he said. Giago's columns won him the coveted H.L. Mencken prize in 1985, but he gave it back when Mencken's bigotry was revealed in the posthumous publication of his diaries. Now he has set himself the challenge of bringing the Indian point of view to the genteel setting of Harvard Yard. ``I don't come here as Tim Giago doing this as myself,'' he said. ``I'm here as a member of the Oglala Sioux Tribe. What I bring back will benefit the tribe.''

DOC.HEAD: President Dissolves Secret Police
DOC.TEXT: President Chadli Bendjedid has ordered Algeria's secret police dissolved in a move seen as a sign of his wish to appease pro-democracy forces in this North African nation. The move comes on the eve of the return from exile this week of former President Ahmed Ben Bella and about six months before legislative elections that could give Algeria its first multiparty Parliament in nearly 30 years. Ben Bella and other opposition leaders had called for the dissolution of the secret police unit as a sign of real democratization. In an announcement late Saturday, the government said the General Delegation for Documentation and Security, known as the DGDS, would be replaced by an intelligence branch dealing exclusively with counter-espionnage. The existence of the secret police was only made official with the resignation announcement Sept. 5 of its director, Gen. Mohammed Betchine. He had been given the post after October 1988 riots. Scores of citizens, mainly youths, were killed in the riots, which set in motion the process that is expected to lead to a multiparty system. The National Liberation Front has ruled Algeria since its independence from France in 1962. Ben Bella led the struggle but was overthrown in a coup d'etat, imprisoned and sent into exile in Switzerland. The main opposition group is currently the Islamic Salvation Front, a Moslem fundamentalist group that won June 12 municipal and provincial elections.

DOC.HEAD: Famed Illusionists Mark 10,000th Show in Vegas
DOC.TEXT: Two decades ago, illusionists Siegfried & Roy were told to forget their dream of bringing their act to this entertainment capital because ``magic doesn't work in Vegas.'' Now, some 10,000 shows and tens of millions of dollars later, they are the architects of one of America's hottest attractions, the top draw in a city of stars, and are building on a dream to save the rare white tiger. When Siegfried & Roy take the stage at the Mirage Hotel Monday night, it will mark the 10,000th live performance in the city they have adopted as their home. By comparison, the longest running show on Broadway, ``A Chorus Line,'' closed this year after 6,137 performances. Today Siegfried Fishbacher and Roy Horn rank No. 27 on Forbes magazine's list of highest-paid performers, ahead of the likes of Frank Sinatra, Tom Cruise and the rock group U2. They're forecast to earn $28 million in the two-year period ending in December. But it was a different story 20 years ago when the two illusionists, who met and formed their act on a cruise ship, tried to break into the Las Vegas market. ``Don't tell me you're a magician because magic doesn't work in Las Vegas,'' a jaded Tropicana Hotel official told the pair before reluctantly giving them a short contract. ``All my confidence was gone,'' Siegfried said during an interview at the pair's walled estate, where they keep a menagerie of animals used in their act and breed white tigers. ``But when I performed here the first time, I knew it was meant to be.'' History has proven the pair right, and their performance is proving Mirage owner Steve Wynn something of a prophet. Wynn announced three years ago he was signing the pair to a $57.5 million, five-year contract as the star attraction when his new $630 million Strip resort opened. The mammoth pact prompted some skepticism of whether Wynn could make their magic pay. The skepticism was short-lived when Siegfried & Roy began packing the new 1,500-seat, $50 million Theatre Mirage two shows a night Feb. 1. The show's producer, Kenneth Feld, said Siegfried & Roy will gross $30 million their first year at the Mirage. They spent eight months performing in Japan in 1988-89. ``The Japanese really spoiled us,'' Roy said, taking a break in a breakfast room overlooking a pool where some of their white tigers played. ``After one performance they continued to applaud for an hour and eight minutes. It was unbelievable.'' The performers returned from Japan for a record-breaking stint at Radio City Music Hall in New York City before heading back to Las Vegas. The extravagant, Broadway-type production mixes spectacular illusions such as a woman appearing to be turned into a 750-pound white tiger with singing and dancing by a 170-member cast. But the show is not the only interest of the two stars. Preservation of the white tiger - a beautiful animal first sighted in the Himalayas 200 years ago and now nearing extinction - is a major goal for Siegfried & Roy. In 1987, zoo officials said there were only about 100 white tigers in the world. All were in captivity. ``The white tigers are our living legacy,'' Roy said. Their collection of 23 whites, including five snow white tigers, is the largest in the world. The performers have started an exchange program with a West German zoo, and are working with the Cincinnati Zoo on a white tiger breeding program. Six rare white tigers were born while the performers were in Japan. Three of them, named Red, White and Blue, were born on July 4, 1989. The white tigers romp and swim at their compound, on the northwest side of Las Vegas, and at an 80-acre ranch on the outskirts of the city. The animals also spend some time, two or three at a time, in an elaborate glassed-in habitat at the Mirage, where millions of people have viewed the animals since the hotel opened in November 1989. Siegfried's most poignant memory? When two white tigers were born at the entertainers compound, and their mother, Sitarra, placed each of the cubs in Roy's lap after they were born - a touching display of trust between animal and man. ``This was the most magical moment of my life,'' Siegfried said.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Firefighters Battle Blazes in South of France
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of firefighters fought Sunday to stamp out three blazes ravaging the Mediterranean forest and destroying coastal homes. But the high winds and bone-dry tinderland hindered their efforts. The 2,500 firefighters and soldiers, backed by 13 planes dousing the forests, stopped the flames from spreading. But the fires continued to devastate the areas already touched, fire authorities said. They said 27,180 acres of land had been burned since Friday in the Var region. Three separate fires continued to rage. One of them, which started Saturday, entered the inland town of Draguignan, destroying some homes and forcing the evacuation of three neighborhoods as bottles of gas exploded from the heat, officials said. High winds, sometimes reaching 50 mph, coupled with tinderland baked dry by a drought complicated the firefighters' task, officials said. About 1,000 homes, most of them around the coastal town of Sainte-Maxime, were without telephone service after flames destroyed telephone poles and 18 miles of cable, France Telecom said. Sainte-Maxime and nearby Roquebrune-sur-Argens were the site of the fiercest blazes, with about 20,000 acres of land destroyed. Fires, some the result of arson, have already devoured tens of thousands of acres of Mediterranean forest this summer.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Arrives for First US-South African Summit in 45 Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Aside from early evening EDT photo op with Vice President Dan Quayle, there are no public events on de Klerk's schedule for Sunday. This should stand.
DOC.TEXT: South African President F.W. de Klerk arrived Sunday for talks with President Bush on ways in which the United States can help that country bring about a peaceful transition to a non-racial system. But the visit, the highlight of which will be a lengthy White House discussion on Monday, has been clouded by an upsurge of violence that has claimed more than 750 lives in black South African townships in recent weeks. Still, Bush's encounter with de Klerk is something of a milestone in U.S.-South African relations. No South African head of state has visited Washington since 1945 and the two countries were barely on speaking terms as recently as a few years ago. De Klerk said on arrival Sunday he was bringing a message of hope for the future of his country and for all of southern Africa. ``We are proceeding irreversibly on the road to a new South Africa, where justice, the guarantees of constitutional democracy and the rule of law will bring lasting peace and prosperity to all our people,'' de Klerk said. His stay here ends Tuesday night. A senior administration official who briefed reporters on Friday said the invitation to de Klerk recognizes the ``bold leadership'' he has provided in seeking a way out of the apartheid era in South Africa. During the talks, Bush will explore ``what role the United States can play in helping to promote the negotiating process in that country,'' said the official, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``Our interest is to promote a peaceful transition, through negotiations, to a post-apartheid, democratic, non-racial South Africa,'' he said. Congress has approved $10 million to give impetus to the negotiating process. The official said the visit was not designed to bring about an end to the economic sanctions the United States imposed against South Africa in 1986. South Africa has fulfilled some but not all of the requirements the legislation imposes for the sanctions to be lifted. The sanctions included a ban on new U.S. investment in South Africa and suspension of landing rights for South African planes in the United States. Officials have said the sanctions can be lifted once South Africa's remaining political prisoners are released and the state of emergency is lifted in Natal Province. Emergency rule was ended elsewhere in South Africa earlier this year. De Klerk said Saturday before his departure from Pretoria that the sanctions will not be a major focus of his visit. ``I'm not going hat in hand with the particular objective of getting sanctions lifted,'' he said. De Klerk will meet with congressional leaders, but the Congressional Black Caucus announced Saturday it had canceled a scheduled meeting with de Klerk, saying only that the decision was in response to ``recent developments in South Africa and after extensive consultation with anti-apartheid activists.'' The decision may have been related to the recent upsurge in violence in the black townships. African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, who was here in late June, has held pro-apartheid security elements of the police and military responsible and said that Americans should demand from de Klerk an explanation for this situation. South African officials themselves have not dismissed this possibility. The Lawyer's Committee for Civil Rights Under Law, a private, Washington-based group, has challenged de Klerk to ensure that ``police and military assassination squads are fully exposed and completely disbanded.''

DOC.HEAD: Celebrations Of Saudi National Day Canceled
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia canceled all official celebrations of the kingdom's National Day holiday Sunday as a gesture of solidarity with the Kuwaiti people. The official Saudi Press Agency said a statement from the royal court had informed Saudi embassies worldwide to refrain from official celebrations because of the suffering endured by the Kuwaiti people since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion. National Day, the government's official day to celebrate the 1932 consolidation of power by King Adbul Aziz, is traditionally celebrated with parades and festivals.

DOC.HEAD: Mubarak Orders Inquiry Into Deaths of Egyptians in Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Hosni Mubarak has ordered an inquiry into the deaths of at least 24 Egyptians that Egypt says were killed in Iraq in recent months. Interior Minister Abdel-Halim Moussa said Iraqi authorities have tried to cover up the slayings by wrapping up the bodies in coffins or claiming they died naturally from internal bleeding or skull fractures. He said some of the victims were slain on the Iraqi-Jordanian border. There was no immediate word from Baghdad. Tens of thousands of Egyptians have fled into Jordan since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Egypt has about 5,000 troops in Saudi Arabia as part of a U.S.-led multinational force that is enforcing a U.N. trade embargo on Iraq. Moussa said Mubarak's order for an investigation was made at a meeting Saturday. He said the 24 bodies have been returned from Iraq since the Iraqi invasion. In a statement to the state-owned newspaper Al-Ahram, Moussa said his ministry has reliable information that all of them were killed by the Iraqis.

DOC.HEAD: Comedian Out For Respect, Gets Little In Injury Trial
LaserPhoto NY12
DOC.TEXT: Comedian Rodney Dangerfield says he just wants to make people laugh, but lawyers for a casino-hotel have portrayed him as a foul-mouthed malingerer with a vindictive streak. ``You're trying to make me out to be a liar and I'm not,'' Dangerfield said at one point during three days of often combative testimony in his $5 million lawsuit against Caesars Palace. For the last two weeks, Dangerfield and Caesars Palace have been locked in a bitter court fight over an eye injury the comedian says he suffered in a steam bath when a burst of steam hit him in the face in March 1988. Jurors are expected to decide sometime this week whether the man who gets no respect suffered lasting eye damage or whether Caesars, which filed a countersuit, should be compensated because he missed five shows. ``The injuries were a figment of his fertile comedic imagination,'' said Caesars attorney Louis Meisinger, who called the 68-year-old comic a ``petulant performer'' in opening arguments. Dangerfield, known for film comedies such as ``Caddyshack'' and ``Back to School'' as well as his standup act, wasn't in a funny mood. ``The last thing I wanted was to be involved in this,'' he said. ``I'm happy when I'm writing jokes and making people laugh.'' Dangerfield said he was determined to win his battle against the resort where he once starred before sold-out audiences. Since the accident, he has worked at Ballys. ``It's very costly for me to do this but I had to do it because I know I'm right,'' Dangerfield said. ``I'm not trying to get even with anybody, but I wasn't treated right and I couldn't walk away from this.'' Dangerfield complained on the witness stand that Caesars executives didn't fully believe he was injured in the incident following the opening night of a week-long performance. ``I was shocked at how they would handle this thing,'' Dangerfield testified. ``I never heard of such a lack of compassion in my life.'' He skipped four performances, claiming his eyes were too sensitive to light to perform. After returning for two shows, he walked offstage without performing on closing night, miffed at Caesars for wanting to withhold his $45,000-a-show fee for the nights he missed. ``I just couldn't be funny for these people,'' said Dangerfield, who advised the showroom crowd of 1,200 to get refunds, even for any tips they gave showroom workers. Caesars introduced evidence showing Dangerfield went to the fights one night he didn't perform, and to see a comedy show another night. A doctor who examined him after the steam incident said he thought Dangerfield could perform. Eye specialists testified that symptoms Dangerfield claims he has had since the accident first appeared in the mid-1970s. They said Dangerfield may have hurt himself further by his repeated use over the years of a topical anesthetic used in surgery on his eyes. If Dangerfield thought he was treated roughly in court, it could have been worse. Caesars attorneys filed documents with the court alleging he was a chronic drinker who frequently used marijuana and cocaine. U.S. District Judge Roger Foley ruled against allowing evidence of substance abuse to be presented to jurors, but allowed testimony that portrayed Dangerfield as being in a drunken stupor following the accident. The testimony came in the form of a deposition from an aspiring screenwriter. Jeffrey Schimmel said he met Dangerfield the day of the accident and stayed with him in New York for several months while they worked on a script. Schimmel, who admitted having a fallout with Dangerfield over the script, testified that the comedian never complained of his eye injury and instead seemed to be on a vendetta against Caesars. ``He was very vindictive,'' Schimmel said. ``He didn't care how much it cost or how much trouble it cost him. He said it would cost them (Caesars) a lot more. He wanted to teach Caesars Palace a lesson.''

DOC.HEAD: Mandela: Police Measures Timed for De Klerk's U.S. Visit
With AM-US-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela said Sunday that new police measures in violence-plagued black townships were timed to create an appearance of calm during President F.W. de Klerk's trip to Washington. ``They pretend de Klerk has put an end to the violence,'' said Mandela, leader of the African National Congress. ``That's not true.'' Mandela also said ANC president Oliver Tambo, recovering from a stroke in Sweden, would attend an ANC congress in South Africa scheduled for Dec. 16. Tambo has been in exile for more than 25 years. ANC officials have said they don't expect Tambo to resume full control of the organization. Mandela, as deputy presidnet, is considered the de facto leader. De Klerk arrived Sunday in Washington to begin a three-day trip. He is the first South African leader in decades to visit the United States, which has imposed economic sanctions to protest the apartheid system of racial segregation and white dominance. ``South Africa has embarked on a great journey,'' de Klerk said upon arrival. ``It is a journey toward full democracy at home, and abroad, full participation in the family of nations.'' De Klerk has pledged to end apartheid and led the government in talks with the ANC on power-sharing. His trip comes after weeks of violence in black townships around Johannesburg that has killed about 800 people. The fighting has pitted Zulu supporters of the conservative Inkatha movement against Xhosas and other blacks linked to the ANC. It spread to the townships in early August from eastern Natal Province, the traditional Zulu homeland, where 5,000 blacks have died in five years of factional fighting. Police reported the townships quiet Sunday, continuing a lull in the violence. But police said two off-duty constables were stoned to death in a dispute with taxi drivers in Natal. It was not known if the killings were linked to the ongoing Inkatha-ANC rivalry. Mandela and other black leaders have blamed police and soldiers for instigating the township fighting by using unnecessary force and siding with Inkatha supporters. The government denies the charges. Mandela also has warned that the government's failure to stop the fighting could jeopardize the peace talks, which started in May. But he said Sunday the white-led government and ANC were ``compelled to work together through thick and thin'' for peaceful change in South Africa. Another black opposition movement, the radical Pan-Africanist Congress, put off a decision on the government's invitation for direct talks on ending apartheid and sharing power with the black majority. The group said Sunday after a leadership meeting in Zimbabwe its ``grassroots branches'' in South Africa would make the decision before a national conference scheduled for November. It has previously rejected proposed power-sharing, saying the only subject for negotiation was the transfer of power to blacks. The new police measures, code-named ``Operation Iron Fist,'' included roadblocks, weapons searches, more police and military reinforcements, and isolating flash points such as worker hostels and squatter camps with razor wire. An overnight curfew in some black townships is scheduled to take effect Tuesday. Some 3,000 people marched Saturday on municipal government offices in Soweto to protest the police measures. Mandela has said the measures were intended to leave blacks powerless and would fail. ``We hope the government will come to its senses to solve the violence not through iron fist, but by putting their arms away,'' he said Sunday. Gerrit Viljoen, the minister of constitutional development, said Saturday the ANC bears responsibility for the faction fighting and should stop blaming white authorities. Government officials said before de Klerk's departure that they believe the ANC rejected the police measures to try to undermine the trip.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Urges Italians to Unite Against Mafia
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II on Sunday deplored the assassination of a Sicilian judge who had been investigating the Mafia and urged Italians to unite in the fight against organized crime. The pontiff, on a two-day visit to this city in northeastern Italy, departed from his prepared speeches to express regret over Friday's slaying of judge Rosario Livantino. The 38-year-old magistrate, who had been investigating Mafia activities for 10 years, was ambushed and shot to death as he drove to his office in Agrigento, Sicily. Police are focusing their investigation on several Mafia clans. Speaking to a crowd of tens of thousands of people following an open-air Mass in central Ferrara, John Paul said the killing was a ``very grave incident of criminality which unfortunately adds to the list of many acts of violence committed recently'' in Italy. ``All Italians, I ask you at this moment to show firmness and courage to stem the growing threat coming from the culture of death,'' the pope said. ``Enough with (the spilling of) innocent blood, enough with mourning and suffering,'' he said. ``May all the forces of the country unite to proclaim aloud the will to live peacefully and to build a society respectful of man and his dignity.'' President Francesco Cossiga, meanwhile, told reporters Sunday that organized crime ``seems to have taken control of part of the national territory.'' ``It's not a matter of common crime, but an attack on the security of the state and the republic,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Will Debt Crisis Erode U.S. Ability To Act Overseas?
DOC.TEXT: By JIM DRINKARD=

The crisis in the Persian Gulf has intensified a new American dilemma: how a country can at once be a superpower and a superpauper. Experts agree the United States is the only nation that can project its military power throughout the world. Yet it also is the world's largest debtor nation, facing a staggering annual deficit, and now the risk of recession. Paying the price for the international effort to squeeze Iraq makes a difficult situation even worse - and the Bush administration signaled last week it would turn to unconventional means: direct aid from allies. No sooner had Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady returned home with billions of dollars in allied aid pledges than a top State Department official said President Bush would rely increasingly on such approaches. ``A kind of a new invention in the practice of diplomacy,'' Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger described it. ``I would expect you will see this administration approaching foreign policy questions more and more in that direction.'' The shift was welcomed in Congress, where lawmakers are struggling to find room in a deficit-ridden budget to provide additional foreign aid to emerging democracies in Eastern Europe and Central America. ``It's not a question of being mercenaries, or `rent-a-superpower,''' said Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind. ``We are the only ones who can do this ... at this moment. We are unique,'' Lugar said of massive, U.S.-led effort against Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Some, however, questioned the new strategy. ``This is a Band-Aid approach,'' said Robert Kurz, a former congressional foreign policy aide who now is at Brookings Institution. ``It's a very, very shortsighted view of the nature of the crisis.'' But that was not the prevailing view in Congress - as long as lawmakers maintain control of the purse strings. Rep. David Obey, D-Wis., acknowledged the need for outside help and said it may be necessary again in the future ``for limited purposes, for a limited period.'' Obey added, however, that the dependence on other countries limits U.S. flexibility. He blamed it on budget deficits run up under the last administration that have left foreign capital to finance U.S. debt, the world's largest. ``The Reagan budget deficits and trade deficits have drained this country of the ability to control its own policy and its own destiny,'' he said. Whatever the cause, the United States is confronted not only with the sudden costs of a massive military deployment in the gulf, estimated at $15 billion over the coming year, but with the need to help allies who have been militarily and economically threatened by the crisis. In addition, the United States owes some $500 million in unpaid past dues to the United Nations, an embarrassing situation at a time when Bush has relied on the world body as the hub of his diplomatic efforts against Iraq. Baker and Brady returned home with $20 billion in pledges. Roughly half of that will go to aid countries harmed by the United Nations embargo imposed against Iraq. The other half will go to offset U.S. costs. Bush wants to forgive $6.7 billion in Egyptian debt as a means of rewarding Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak's leadership in the gulf crisis; frontline states such as Turkey and Jordan have been hit hard economically by the Iraqi embargo; and Israel is claiming the need for new weapons to maintain its security in the increasingly volatile region. To some analysts, using the solicitation of other countries as any kind of long-term method of financing foreign policy represents yet another evasion of American money problems. ``We have a very strong interest in much higher levels of foreign aid, and much lower levels of military spending,'' said Kurz of the Brookings. ``The world has changed, but we are having a hard time accommodating to it.'' The United States is the world's only remaining superpower, now that the Soviet Union is withdrawing from its empire and focusing on domestic problems, Kurz said. It has the only military force which can be quickly projected around the world. In the future, threats to U.S. interests are more likely to come from third-world conflicts such as the clash between Iraq and Kuwait than from the traditional bipolar rivalry with the Soviet Union, he said. It would be much cheaper to head off those problems through increased foreign aid and trade than to intervene militarily, but the United States has not yet gotten used to the idea, said Kurz.

DOC.HEAD: New Orleans Teachers Say Central Strike Issue is Dignity, Not Money
LaserPhoto NU1
DOC.TEXT: The picket signs read ``No raise, no work.'' But for many of the 3,000 teachers on strike in New Orleans, it's a matter of toilet paper, discipline and dignity. ``When teachers strike, you know it's more than just the pay. If all it was was money, they wouldn't be teaching in the first place,'' said Mike Stone, an English teacher at McMain Magnet Secondary School. United Teachers of New Orleans, which represents the New Orleans Parish's 4,420 teachers and 1,100 teachers' aides and secretaries, went on strike Sept. 17. The district kept schools open with substitutes and a little more than 1,600 regular teachers who crossed picket lines last week. On Friday, 62,277 of the district's estimated 85,000 students attended classes. Union officials say a dispute over who would bear the burden of $400,000 in health insurance costs - the teachers or the district - triggered last week's walkout that has disrupted education in the state's largest school district. But New Orleans Parish teachers on the picket lines say the issues are not only increased insurance costs, but poor working conditions, discipline and the feeling that many parents regard them as overpaid baby sitters. One picket at Lafayette Elementary School last week wrapped her sign in toilet paper. ``Dr. Williams, yes it's true. We provide toilet paper. Here's some for you,'' proclaimed the sign addressed to Superintendent Everett Williams. Other teachers have complained of spending as much as $500 a year of their own money to buy paper, workbooks and other instructional supplies. District officials deny such charges. ``I can assure you there's enough hand towels and toilet tissue in New Orleans public schools. Teachers are not buying them out of their private funds in any numbers that I know of,'' said the district's chief negotiator, Frank Fudesco. ``The reason is money,'' school board spokesman Henry Joubert said flatly. Teachers also complained that the administration isn't backing them on discipline of students and wastes money on adminstrators who drive new cars equipped with telephones. ``Students are hitting teachers,'' said Ann Legaux who teaches gifted children at Fannie Williams Middle School. ``Do you think they're going to be expelled, as it says in the handbook? No. They're back the next day.'' District officials refused to discuss student discipline policies. However, the district said the cars in question are two years old, are leased and needed by seven administrators whose jobs require regular visits to schools around the city. Before last week's strike, teachers had dropped earlier demands for 10 percent pay raises, saying they would settle instead for having the district provide $1 million to cover half of a $300-per-person increase in health insurance costs. Management offered $600,000, saying that was all the district could afford. After the walkout, teachers reinstated their demand for 10 percent raises as well as the $1 million insurance package. Salaries range from $19,455 for a starting teacher to $35,111 for someone with a doctorate and 25 years experience. But the teachers insist the real issue is respect. ``The real problem is the school board and top administration,'' said Ellen Picou, a school librarian. ``We're on the picket line here on Claiborne Avenue because the school board ... has no idea how teachers feel.''

DOC.HEAD: Rash of Suicide Attempts Over Jobs Policy Continues
DOC.TEXT: An unemployed upper-caste man tried to posion himself Sunday to protest a new policy reserving federal jobs for low-caste Hindus. The policy has set off a wave of suicide attempts. Jatinder Vaid of Ambala, about 130 miles north of New Delhi, ate some ``poisonous tablets,'' but survived after being taken to a hospital, Press Trust of India reported. On Friday, Vaid had tried to jump into a bus set on fire by rampaging students, but was rescued by friends, the agency reported. Another news agency, United News of India, said Akhilesh Pandey, a student in the central town of Gwalior, doused his body with kerosene Saturday and tried to burn himself, but was stopped in time. The suicide attempt triggered anti-government riots in the industrial town, about 170 miles southeast of New Delhi. Troops have been deployed in at least four areas to control mobs that have destroyed vehicles and burned government buildings to protest the decision to reserve 49 percent of federal jobs for low-caste Hindus. Another 5 percent to 10 percent of the jobs will be reserved for the poor, regardless of their caste. The government says the affirmative action program will help Indianswwho have suffered for centuries under the rigid caste system, which sets social levels. Opponents of the policy say qualified students of higher castes will lose the coveted government jobs to unqualified workers. The government employs about 18 million people. At least 25 people have died in clashes with police since Aug. 7 when Prime Minister V.P. Singh announced the policy. In the Hindu holy city of Kurukshetra, about 95 miles north of New Delhi, a a 16-year-old high school student died Saturday after eating insecticide. A suicide note by Sushil Kumar blamed the incident on the jobs policy, police said in Chandigarh. Chandigarh police had initially reported that Kumar was 23 years old and that he burned himself to death. Police officials Sunday said the erroneous report was based on information received from the remote town. On Saturday, about 14 students in the western Rajasthan state tried to burn themselves with kerosene, but were stopped by police, the Hindustan Times newspaper reported. It said some of the students also jumped into a bonfire of effigies of government ministers, but were pulled out. The first student to attempt suicide over the jobs policy, Rajeev Goswami, was in critical condition in a New Delhi hospital Sunday with burns over 55 percent of his body. The 20-year-old student set himself ablaze with kerosene on Wednesday. Thousands of students continued a sit-in for the third day Sunday outside Safdarjang hospital where Goswami is admitted. The students have set up camp on a road outside the hospital, blocking traffic between southern residential neighborhood and central districts. On Sunday, the Delhi University said it was closing until Wednesday because of the ``volatile situation.''

DOC.HEAD: Opposing Forces in the Gulf
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a breakdown of the opposing forces in the Persian Gulf: --- IRAQ: Baghdad has fifty-five army divisions with an estimated 555,000 regular troops and 480,000 reserves. Regular forces include seven divisions of elite Republican Guards. Iraq claims a militia called the Popular Army has 5 million men. Baghdad's armory has 5,500 tanks, 3,500 heavy artillery guns; 200 multiple rocket launchers; an estimated 500 surface-to-surface missiles; 330 surface-to-air missile launchers; 500-plus combat airctaft, including Soviet-supplied long-range Su-24 fighter-bombers and advanced MiG-29 interceptors. It main naval units are a training frigate with anti-submarine torpedoes, an estimated eight Soviet-built missile-attack craft and six torpedo boats. In Kuwait, Iraq has an estimated 10 divisions, four of them armored, totaling 170,000 troops, 1,500 T-55 and T-62 tanks and 700 artillery pieces. A further 150,000 men, including the seven Republican Guard divisions with up to 1,300 tanks and 750 guns, are dug in in southern Iraq. Silkworm anti-ship missiles are believed to have been deployed to counter any U.S. amphibious landing in Kuwait. ---

The multinational force that is facing Iraq includes:
UNITED STATES: Officials say more than 165,000 troops, including those aboard ships, are in the gulf region or en route. Deployments could go as high as 250,000 in the biggest U.S. military operation since Vietnam. Ground forces include the 82nd ``All American'' Airborne Division, the 101st ``Screaming Eagles'' Airborne Division, the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division, with some 200 M-1 Abrams tanks and 300 Bradley Fighting Vehicles, the 11th Air Defense Artillery Brigade, 197th Mechanized Infantry Brigade and the 3rd Armored Cavalry Regiment. Amphibious capability is provided by 45,000 men of the 1st, 4th and 6th Marine Expeditionary Brigades. There is a Special Forces contingent from the 1st Special Operations Command. The U.S. deployment is expected to be complete by late October, when the Americans will have around 1,000 tanks in Saudi Arabia. More than 50 U.S. warships are in the gulf, the Arabian Sea and the eastern Mediterranean, including the aircraft carriers Indepndence, Saratoga and John F. Kennedy. Another seven ships are expected in the Mediterranean. The Pentagon has also sent 22 F117A Stealth fighter-bombers to unspecified bases, 14 long-range F-111F bombers to Incirlik airbase, in southwest Turkey, and another squadron to Spain.
BRITAIN: It has 10 ships in the gulf, ships, including a missile destroyer, two missile frigates and three minesweepers. Three squadrons of Tornado and Jaguar interceptors and ground attack jets are in Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and Oman. At lease one more Tornado squadron will arrive soon. Three Nimrod maritime reconnaisance aircraft are in Oman. The British force totals 3,000 personnel, with 2,000 logistics personnel at a staging post in Cyprus, where the British have sovereign bases. The 7th Armored Brigade, successors to the famous ``Desert Rats'' of World War II, will arrive late next month with 120 Challenger tanks and 6,000 troops. FRANCE: It has some 14 ships, with an estimated 8,000 men, are in the gulf or en route, including the carrier Clemenceau with 42 combat helicopters, a guided-missile cruiser, two missile destroyers, two frigates and one corvette. The fleet tanker Var is also being deployed. A company of 190 paratroopers equipped for chemical warfare is in the United Arab Emirates. France is sending three squadrons of interceptors and fighter-bombers. The first elements of a 4,000-man rapid deployment force arrived in Saudi Arabia on Sunday. French strength will rise to 13,000 when the deployment is completed.
SOVIET UNION: It has sent the Udaloy-class destroyer Admiral Tributs and an anti-submarine ship to the Gulf of Oman. Moscow has indicated it would send ground forces, but only under U.N. command.
GREECE: Greece has sent its most advanced frigate, the Limnos, to the eastern Mediterranean.
ITALY: The frigates Libeccio and Orsa and a support ship, the Stromboli, are in the gulf. Two corvettes are in the eastern Mediterranean. Italy says it will send an another warship and eight Tornado fighter jets.
NETHERLANDS: Two frigates are in the Gulf of Oman. A combat supply ship is expected there in November.
WEST GERMANY: Bonn is providing merchant ships to transport U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia and has committed $2 billion toward the multinational force. West Germany's constitution prohibits it committing military forces.
SPAIN: The frigate Santa Maria is in the Gulf of Oman. Two corvettes are in the southern Red Sea.
DENMARK: It has sent a corvette to the gulf region.
NORWAY: It will send a coast guard cutter to support the Danish corvette. Norway has offered anti-chemical warfare equipment.
AUSTRALIA: Two guided-missile frigates and a supply ship are in the gulf region.
BELGIUM: Two minehunters and a supply ship are in the Gulf of Oman.
CANADA: Two destroyers and a supply ship are heading for the gulf. A squadron of 12 fighter jets will be sent.
ARGENTINA: A destroyer and a frigate sailed for the gulf Saturday and are expected to arrive mid-October. ---

Allied Arab Forces:
GULF COOPERATION COUNCIL (Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Oman, United Arab Emirates, Qatar and, until Aug. 2, Kuwait): A rapid deployment force of up to 10,000 troops is based at Hafer al-Batin, northeast Saudi Arabia and 40 miles south of the Kuwait border. It has been beefed up with some 7,000 soldiers of Kuwait's 20,000-man who escaped their country when Iraq invaded. The GCC and other local Arab forces in the Gulf total around 144,500 men, 330 combat aircraft, 800 tanks and 36 major naval units. They are supported by:
EGYPT: It has pledged up to 30,000 troops with tanks and heavy artillery. Some 5,000 troops, including paratroopers, commandos, chemical warfare specialists and infantry, are in Saudi Arabia and several thousands more from the 15,000-man 4th Infantry Division are en route. Five hundred troops are in the U.A.E.
PAKISTAN: Pledged to send 5,000 troops, and 2,000 have been sent to the U.A.E.
MOROCCO: 1,200 troops in Saudi Arabia and 500 in the U.A.E.
SYRIA: 4,000 troops, mostly special forces, sent to Saudi Arabia, and is planning to send 15,000 more. Some troops are based in the U.A.E.
BANGLADESH: 3,000 troops pledged. 2,000 are in Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: Tremors Rattle Northern California But Cause No Injuries or Damage
DOC.TEXT: Two mild earthquakes rattled Northern California over the weekend but caused no injuries or damage, authorities said Sunday. A temblor registering 3.0 on the Richter scale occurred on the San Francisco Peninsula at 6:36 a.m. Sunday, the state Office of Emergency Services said. It was centered seven miles southwest of Menlo Park, 23 miles south of San Francisco. A 4.0 quake occurred at 8 p.m. Saturday three miles south of San Juan Bautista, about 35 miles south of San Francisco, the office of Emergency Services said. The readings for both quakes, measured by the U.S. Geological Survey, were preliminary, the state office said. Scientists say a quake measuring 3.0 on the Richter scale of ground motion can cause slight damage in the immediate area and a 4.0 quake can cause moderate damage.

DOC.HEAD: Cambodia's Prime Minister Replaced In Second Job As Foreign Minister
DOC.TEXT: Hun Sen has been replaced as Cambodia's foreign minister, and the country's official radio said the change was made to give him more time for his duties as prime minister. The new foreign minister is Hor Nam Hong, who had been a minister in charge of foreign affairs in the prime minister's office. The Communist Party Politburo made the decision Monday to try to ease Hun Sen's duties, said the broadcast, a text of which was seen in Bangkok on Sunday. The change comes as the government, which Vietnam installed in a 1978 invasion, is involved in crucial peace talks with three guerrilla groups. The first meeting of a council helping to oversee Cambodia's transition to an elected government collapsed last week in a dispute over the future role of resistance leader Prince Norodom Sihanouk. Sihanouk later asked his guerrilla allies to yield to the government demand on the issue. Thailand has said it would agree to be the host of another meeting of the Supreme National Council. The council was formed under a U.N. peace plan is to work with the world body to end an 11-year-old civil war. Cambodian radio also announced the transfer of the deputy foreign minister, Dit Munti, to chairman of the Central Propaganda and Education Commission. No reason was given for the move.

DOC.HEAD: West Reported Receptive Toward Resuming Credit for China
DOC.TEXT: Western nations have become more receptive to Japanese efforts to resume international lending to China which was halted in 1989 because of Beijing's brutal crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators. ``Our European friends expressed readiness to increase the possibility of loans to China,'' said Ryutaro Hashimoto, Japan's finance minister, following a weekend meeting of the Group of Seven, the world's wealthiest industrial countries. The group which includes the United States, Japan, West Germany Britain, France, Italy and Canada commands decisive voting power in the World Bank. The G-7 met in conjunction with this week's annual meetings of the bank and its sister lending organization, the 152-nation International Monetary Fund. Hashimoto said the atmosphere at this meeting was decidedly different from last July's economic summit in Houston when Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said his government intended gradually to resume direct loans to Beijing that were held up after suppression of the democracy movement. Hashimoto, a member of Kaifu's cabinet, said he told the group ``we should give forthcoming consideration to loans conducive to economic reform in China, especially in areas related to protection of the environment.'' The United States said it understood Kaifu's view that stability and reform should be promoted in China and that the world's most populous country should not be isolated. ``During these economic meetings, there will be discussions about the future program and hopefully a quick normalization of bank lending activities in China,'' said Attila Karaosmanoglu of Turkey, World Bank's vice president for Asia. ``We do hope the situation can be normalized in the not too distant future,'' he added. The group had said it would only support investments in China related to basic human needs the government's June 1989 crackdown. With more than $2 billion worth of projects in the pipeline, loan approvals in 1989 were limited to $590 million. Earlier this year, however, ``the same G-7 expressed willingness to vote for financing basic human needs plus environment-related projects, plus implementation of economic reforms,'' Karaosmanoglu said. ``We are continuing with preparation of these projects,'' he added. China's democracy crackdown coincided with an economic crisis in which purchasing power had outrun production and triggered inflation, Karaosmanoglu recalled. Since then, he continued, austerity measures have successfully curbed inflation and boosted exports and foreign exchange. ``In a sense, China is at a crossroads - in the short run, the problem is revival, but the long-run question is how to reactivate the reform process,'' Karaosmanoglu said. The World Bank forecasts economic growth in China this year of 3.5 percent to 4.5 percent, compared to 2 percent last year, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Threatens Oil Fields, Israel if ``Strangled'' by Troops
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq said Sunday it would destroy all Middle East oil fields and move against Israel if its people were ``strangled'' by foreign forces assembling in the Persian Gulf. The statement urged the United States and other foreign powers to drop ``the language of threats'' and adopt a ``climate of understanding.'' But it called Iraq's annexation of Kuwait ``an eternal decision.'' ``We will never allow anybody, whomever he may be, to strangle the people of Iraq without having himself strangled,'' said a joint communique from the Revolution Command Council, Iraq's highest decision-making body, and the ruling Baath Party. ``The oil areas in Saudi Arabia and in other states of the region, all the oil installations, will be rendered incapable ... and Israel will be transformed into something different from what they are now,'' said the statement, broadcast by state-run Radio Baghdad and monitored in Nicosia. ``Israel will be included in all actions that affect the owners of the homeland in which the forces of evil and occupation have settled,'' it said, apparently referring to Saudi Arabia. It added: ``Then will be the flood.'' The communique did not give details about what action could be taken by Iraq. It was issued following a joint meeting of the council and party earlier Sunday presided over by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. The statement lashed out at the U.S.-led military buildup in Saudi Arabia and surrounding waters that began after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Iraq annexed the oil-rich emirate six days later. The troop buildup and subsequent U.N.-supported sanctions imposed on Iraq were ``reckless, odious and foolish behavior,'' it said. Kuwait has been ``restored to its people to be part of its original nation by an eternal decision from which there can be no retreat under any circumstances or conditions,'' the ruling council and party said. It repeatedly condemned the United States. ``America is committing deep criminal acts against Iraq and the Arab nation especially in occuping the Arab and Moslem holy places in Najd and Hejaz (Saudi Arabia), and in its sanctions imposed aainst the Iraqi people in a way that exceeds all humanitarian limits. ``America did all this to satisfy its arrogance and enforce its hegemony on the entire world,'' the statement said. The statement insisted Iraq would not accept any settlement to the gulf crisis unless it was based on Saddam's Aug. 12 peace initiative in which he called for an Israeli withdrawal from Palestinian territories. ``America must realize clearly that it is pushing the entire region ... in fact, even the whole world ... to the brink of a bottomless abyss, from which the region will never see light for dozens of years,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Delays Secret Rocket Launch
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting to restore AP logo
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force on Sunday called off the launch of a Titan 4 rocket with 5 minutes remaining in the countdown because of undisclosed technical problems. The secret launch had been scheduled for shortly after midnight, but was scrubbed about 3{ hours later. It was not known if a new launch date had been set. The Air Force has launched Titan 4 rockets in June 1989 and last June. The latest launch had been scheduled for earlier Thursday, but was delayed because of another undisclosed technical problem. Air Force officials had refused to acknowledge the planned launch from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station. Civilian experts said they believed the rocket holds a missile warning satellite. The Martin Marietta rocket is valued at $173 million.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Pianist Van Cliburn, who has performed before highbrow audiences in some of the world's great concert halls, can add Cornhusker football fans and Nebraska's Memorial Stadium to the list. Cliburn performed the national anthem before the Nebraska-Minnesota game Saturday at the request of his old friend D.B. ``Woody'' Varner, the former University of Nebraska president. ``I'm just extremely flattered to be here,'' Cliburn said. The musician said he met Varner more than 25 years ago when Varner, then chancellor of Oakland University in Rochester, Mich., helped build a performing arts center there. Although Cliburn said he had not played the piano before a football game before, he is no stranger to the sport. ``I was a clarinet player in the Kilgore (Texas) High School marching band,'' he said. ``I have loved football all my life and have marched in many games.'' --- CAPRI, Italy (AP) - President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia received Italy's Malaparte Prize on Sunday for his work as a playwright during his country's hard-line Communist years. The prize is named for Curzio Malaparte, an Italian journalist and short-story writer who died in 1957. Previous winners include Arthur Miller and Samuel Beckett. ``His theatrical works are of great value,'' said the award's jurors. ``They originate from his life experience in a totalitarian system but they always deal with the universal problems of man.'' Havel accepted the award during a ceremony at the Santa Teresa church on this island in the Gulf of Naples. --- DALLAS (AP) - Director Peter Bogdanovich said making the sequel to the 1971 hit movie ``The Last Picture Show'' was more work than fun. ``I wouldn't have been able to make this picture 20 years ago,'' said Bogdanovich, who attended the movie's premiere here Saturday. ``I wouldn't have known how to direct it. You need a little experience to make a picture with this big a canvas.'' It was a more depressing experience for Cybill Shepherd, who reprised her role as Jacy Farrow. Her character comes home to grieve the loss of her 6-year-old son. ``Being the mother of three, it was very, very painful and very difficult,'' she said of the role. The 1971 film made Miss Shepherd a star. The sequel, based on the novel by Larry McMurtry, also reunited Jeff Bridges, Randy Quaid and Cloris Leachman. --- FORTE DEI MARMI, Italy (AP) - American cartoonist Garry Trudeau and author Gore Vidal were honored for political satire and literature. ``Doonesbury'' comic strip creator Trudeau was awarded Italy's Forte dei Marmi Prize for satire. Vidal, best known for his historical novels ``Burr'' and ``Lincoln,'' received the literary award for his book ``Hollywood.'' The two received their awards Saturday in this town near Lucca in Tuscany. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Actor Beau Bridges will portray James Brady in a TV movie about the former White House press secretary severely wounded in the 1981 assassination attempt on President Reagan. ``The James Brady Story'' will chronicle Brady's rise to press secretary and the March 30, 1981 assassination attempt in Washington, D.C., by John Hinckley, said Robert Cooper, senior vice president for HBO Pictures. The David Puttnam-Enigma production will begin filming in November in Houston and Washington, and debut on HBO in spring 1991. The movie was written by Robert Bolt, winner of best screenplay Academy Awards for ``Dr. Zhivago'' and ``A Man for All Seasons.'' Michael Uno, who directed HBO's ``Vietnam War Story,'' will direct the Brady movie. Bridges won a National Society of Film Critics award for his recent role in ``The Fabulous Baker Boys.'' He also was featured in the movies ``The Other Side of the Mountain,'' ``Greased Lightning,'' ``Norma Rae,'' and ``The Hotel New Hampshire.''

DOC.HEAD: Diplomatic, Military Changes Challenge Saudi Arabia
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia marked its 58th birthday Sunday at a crossroads, a time that finds it suddenly reshaping its relations in the Middle East even as it deals with hosting thousands of Western troops. For a country that prides itself on slow, methodical change, the pace is dizzying, and potentially dangerous. At stake is the power structure of the Middle East, the flow of oil to the West and, more personally for the Saudi monarchy, the degree to which the current crisis will foster change in a nation that seeks modernization without what it sees as the negative trappings of the West. The Al-Saud monarchy, known since its inception 58 years ago for its cautious handling of diplomatic matters, moved aggressively Saturday to punish Jordan and Yemen for not breaking with Iraq over the invasion of Kuwait. Riyadh expelled their diplomats and suggested they were assisting Iraqi espionage in the kingdom. ``We have decided it is time to burn bridges,'' is how one Saudi diplomatic official put it. Indeed, as they burn bridges with their neighbors, the Saudis are trying to build them with the West, and Moscow and Beijing as well. But they are unsure how the current crisis will reshape their volatile region. ``It would be convenient if we could wait until all this sorts itself out to decide which course to take,'' another Saudi official said Sunday, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``But this is not a time for convenience. We have waited far too long.'' If nothing else, Saturday's expulsions appeared designed to put extraordinary pressure on Jordan, which relies on generous Saudi aid to help its crippled economy. Saudi sources said the expulsions could soon be followed by a cutoff or sharp reduction in foreign aid. In terms of its influence in Arab affairs, Sauidi Arabia's position as aid donor is second only to its role as the custodian of Islam's holy places. In Amman, Jordanian officials have said the flow of Saudi cash dried up almost immediately after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. But, in the absence of official word from Riyadh, they hoped it might be resumed before too long. ``It is unfortunate that much of our assistance has gone to wasteful things,'' the Saudi diplomatic official said. ``We must be more careful about how we spend our money and who receives it.'' That was not only a warning to Jordan and Yemen, but to Palestinians as well. Immediately after the invasion, the Saudi government suggested that Palestine Liberation Organization chief Yasser Arafat's support of Saddam Hussein would not affect the kingdom's generous aid to Palestinians. That posture has since changed. Several senior Saudi officials have suggested that aid to the Palestinians could be cut off or sharply reduced unless Palestinian leaders break their ties with Baghdad. ``We are realizing that for too long we have gone to great lengths to avoid making tough choices,'' the Saudi diplomatic official said. ``We must now make some, and so must our supposed friends.'' The remarkable breaks with Yemen and Jordan also serve as an admission that the government now realizes it can buy neither friends nor security simply by heaping billions in foreign aid on its neighbors. The Saudis now are promising lucrative assistance to reward the military help coming from Egypt and Syria, the Arab world's two greatest military powers after Iraq. Whether those new alliances will last is suspect, and Saudi Arabia already is promising to improve its military, which was woefully unprepared to deal with the Iraqi invasion. That effort will force the Saudi monarchy to deal with nepotism, which dominates the military, and the role of women, who because of the low Saudi population likely will be needed to fill both military and civilian jobs. Saudi Arabia also appears to have little choice but to be more open about its dealings with the West, particularly the United States. Americans and other Westerners have wielded considerable influence in Saudi economic affairs since the discovery of oil here 50 years ago. The Saudis have tried to keep the extent of these relationships under wraps. In the past seven weeks, however, Saudi Arabia has had to open its doors to hundreds of foreign journalists who converged on the kingdom to report on the gulf crisis. A Saudi prince, interviewed recently, nodded his head virtually non-stop as he read a list of questions on domestic and international issues that King Fahd was being forced to confront all at once. ``That you are here to ask the questions is a sign itself of the rapid change,'' he said. ``And we must deal with this change. But I have no answer today. Right now, nothing is certain.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - John King is an AP writer on assignment in Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers' Departure Hurts Town's Economy
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhoto AX1
DOC.TEXT: With most of the 24th Infantry Division in Saudi Arabia, the clip artists at Curly's Barber Shop spend their days watching television and napping. The deployment of 14,000 GIs from nearby Fort Stewart for what probably will be a lengthy Mideast tour has already hurt businesses in Hinesville and surrounding Liberty County. Howard ``Curly'' Gainous Sr., 69, said his shop used to give 400 haircuts a week, but now is down to 50 or 60. Gainous and Ed Barfield, 68, spend their days in the shop while the four other barbers check in periodically, hoping for work. ``I hope we get enough to hang on. We have high rent and overhead,'' Gainous said. An electric barber pole still spins outside the shop, but Gainous has turned off some lights in a back room to save money. Mayor Buddy DeLoach said fast food sales have been cut by 50 percent and house and apartment rentals are 30 percent below normal. City officials won't know the full economic impact of the deployment until late October, when this month's sales tax receipts are tallied. But DeLoach said there already are plans to delay capital improvements and equipment purchases. Some residents hope the Army will move another division to Fort Stewart, possibly from Germany. But military officials say there are no plans to bring another unit to the 780,000-acre post. Hinesville residents pride themselves on their patriotism and support for the military. Army families live throughout the town. Civilian and military residents socialize, attend the same churches and work together in civic clubs. Fort Stewart was just a sleepy southern Army post until the division was activated there in 1974. Since then, the county's population has jumped from 18,000 to 52,000. Hinesville officials worried about a mass exodus of military families following the deployment, but families with homes and school-age children apparently have remained. Liberty County school enrollment is slightly higher this year - 8,015 students, cmmpared to 7,995 last year. Ronald E. Tolley, executive director of the Liberty County Industrial Authority, said the county has attracted several new industries that will help diversify the economy. Officials will try to boost slumping retail sales by attracting tourists and promoting Hinesville as a regional shopping area. Tolley believes businesses that provided services to the young single soldiers will be especially hard hit. Hinesville has dozens of fast-food restaurants, pawn shops and used car lots. It also has at least nine barber shops, several auto parts stores, two major discount department stores and three large supermarkets. ``I think they're definitely feeling the impact,'' said Tolley. ``You no longer see the military people in the stores.'' Donald Bonett, assistant store manager at the Piggly-Wiggly supermarket, said sales at his store have dropped $30,000 to $40,000 a week. Managers have cut the hours of part-time workers. ``Our sales have dropped - at least one-fourth of what we used to do,'' he said. Only 12 cars were parked at the 52-room Days Inn motel on a recent night. ``It's very, very slow,'' said general manager Mike Patel. ``We depend on the Army.'' Patel said the housekeeping staff has been cut from seven to two. The motel used to have an 80 percent occupancy rate, he said. ``If it stays like this for two months, it's going to be a problem for us. We are losing money,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: `Al Capone' Law Paying Off
DOC.TEXT: Many thought it was a joke when Texas enacted taxes on illegal drugs, but officials say the laugh is on drug dealers as they find themselves in deeper trouble because of the year-old ``Al Capone'' law. The law requires all containers of illegal drugs to carry a tax stamp, emblazoned with either a skull and crossbones or the image of the Grim Reaper and the words ``Death'' and ``Taxes.'' The law requires a tax of $200 per gram on controlled substances, $101.50 per ounce or $3.50 per gram on marijuana. Since the tax took effect on Sept. 1, 1989, more than 2,550 drug stamps have been sold for $10,614, presumably to collectors, since the stamp would be prohibitively expensive in the illegal drug trade. ``The law was never intended to be a source of revenue for the state. It was always intended to give prosecutors another felony charge to put drug dealers behind bars,'' said John Bender, deputy comptroller. ``If we manage to collect some money from drug dealers in addition to that, all the better for the state,'' he said. The state comptroller's office has billed 397 people more than $180 million in unpaid drug taxes. Realistically, the state will collect only a fraction of that amount. But nearly $40,000 has been collected from people who faced criminal tax evasion charges after they were arrested with drugs that did not have the state drug tax stamp. Under the law, criminal tax evasion is a felony which carries a possible prison sentence of two to 10 years and officials can freeze a person's assets to collect the tax. For 48-year-old Odis Weaver of Texarkana, the law meant an additional 10 years for evading taxes on top of a 34-year sentence for possession of cocaine. In addition, the state comptroller's office froze his bank account and collected $1,800. When state Rep. Billy Clemons introduced the drug tax bill in 1987, ``I got laughed out of the House.'' In 1989, he persuaded his colleagues that the tax could be enforced. ``It's nothing unusual. Anything we wish to discourage, we tax.'' He even dubbed it the ``Al Capone'' law after the Prohibition-era gangster who was finally tripped up on federal income tax evasion charges and sent to prison. ``The drug tax seems to be a pretty good tool when all else fails. The evidence is irrefutable. If you don't have the stamp you face a felony charge of tax evasion,'' he said. ``The success of the law will be determined by whether Texas juries are willing to put drug dealers in jail for failure to pay taxes,'' said Sam Ponder, chief of criminal litigation at the Bexar County District Attorney's office. But he added: ``The people who are being charged have very little in the way of assets that can be seized for the payment of taxes. Most of the dealers charged typically have an apartment and car and live from one deal to the next.''

DOC.HEAD: Finance Ministers Differ Over Interest Rates
With AM-World Environment Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The world's richest countries tried hard Sunday to present a unified front against the threat that the Persian Gulf turmoil could plunge the world into a recession, but signs of discord emerged from the closed-door discussions. Finance ministers from Britain, West Germany and France stressed the need for vigor in fighting inflation. But the United States, represented by Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, continued to press its case that lower interest rates were needed to ward off a recession. The discussions were being held as part of the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. The meetings, which involve representatives from 152 nations gained more urgency this year as finance officials struggled to develop a strategy for dealing with the economic fallout from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The finance officials endorsed the broad outlines of a U.S.-led effort to channel billions of dollars to countries hard hit by the Persian Gulf crisis. Those include the so-called frontline states of Turkey, Egypt and Jordan, as well as other Third World countries whose economies have suffered from the loss of markets stemming from the U.N. trade embargo against Iraq and the world rise in oil prices.
