However, British Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major told reporters that decisions regarding specific amounts of assistance and how many countries should be helped remained to be worked out. IMF Managing Director Michel Camdessus has raised the possibility of establishing a voluntary fund, with contributions coming from the windfall profits made by oil-producing nations. Those funds would be made available to the poorer oil-consuming nations. Officials said potential donor nations were to meet to discuss this fund on Wednesday. Brady, in a speech Sunday to the policy-making committee of the IMF, continued to stress the U.S. position that world financial leaders needed to be equally worried about inflation and recession. He said successfully navigating policy to avoid both problems ``will be difficult. But it is achievable.'' But in their remarks, other finance ministers left little doubt that they considered inflation to be the greater threat and thus would not be moving to lower interest rates. ``Without preservation of price stability we would lose on all fronts,'' West German Finance Minister Theo Waigel said. ``The clearer we make our anti-inflationary determination, the quicker we will reduce the risks of financial instability,'' said French Economics Minister Pierre Beregovoy. While the remarks were made in a closed meeting, copies of the speeches were made available to reporters. Major, who briefed reporters following his address, said ``There is nothing to be gained and a great deal to be lost by easing up on inflation. We have to get it down.'' The position of the other countries is likely to make it more difficult for the administration to convince the Federal Reserve of the urgency of reducing U.S. interest rates in the face of growing signs of economic weakness. Some analysts believe the shock to the U.S. economy from the doubling in world oil prices since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait will result in a recession in this country beginning before the end of the year. Faced with this prospect, the administration has been pressuring the Fed to lower interest rates to spur economic activity. However, analysts said they were not looking for the Fed to heed this call in view of the fact that interest rates in other countries have been rising. The widening disparity between U.S. and foreign interest rates has resulted in foreign investors pulling money out of the U.S. market in favor of higher returns overseas. If that trend accelerated, it could trigger a sharp drop in the value of the dollar which would only worsen inflationary pressures in the United States. The other finance leaders emphasized the need for the United States to do something to get its federal budget under control. The world's seven richest countries - the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Canada and Italy - specifically mentioned the U.S. deficit problem in a joint communique issued late Saturday. In his speech Sunday, Brady sought to allay fears that the current negotiations between Congress and the administration will fail to craft a credible deficit reduction agreement. His comments appeared aimed at calls for Congress and the administration to abandon the Gramm-Rudman deficit reduction targets because the $50 billion in deficit reduction being contemplated for the 1991 budget year would be too great a shock on an already weak economy.

DOC.HEAD: Man Held Without Bond In Appalachian Trail Slayings
LaserPhoto HX1
DOC.TEXT: Appalachian Trail Conference officials expressed relief Sunday at the arrest of a man charged with the slayings of two hikers killed in their sleeping bags along the Maine-to-Georgia path. David ``Casey'' Horn, 38, was arrested Friday in Harpers Ferry on a fugitive from justice charge, said Jefferson County Magistrate Patricia Noland. Horn remained in custody without bail Sunday pending an extradition hearing. Noland said Horn was wanted on two homicide charges in Pennsylvania in connection with the Sept. 13 killings of Molly LaRue, 25, of Shaker Heights, Ohio, and Geoffrey Logan Hood, 26, of Signal Mountain, Tenn. ``We're on pins and needles to hear word and get him back here,'' said Pennsylvania State Police Cpl. Dan Sullivan, who heads the murder investigation. Brian King, a spokesman for the Appalachian Trail Conference in Harpers Ferry, said Horn was arrested by U.S. Park Service rangers when he entered the historic Eastern Panhandle town. ``A hiker saw this person answering the description coming across the bridge into Harpers Ferry,'' King said. ``Three park rangers stopped him and took him in for questioning, and they held him for the Pennsylvania State Police and the West Virginia State Police.'' King, whose voluntary group oversees the entire 2,160-mile trail, said hikers were relieved that a suspect had been arrested. He said about 200 people attended a ceremony Saturday to open a new route at Boiling Springs, Pa. ``It was announced about an hour before it started and relief is the best way to describe it,'' he said. ``It's been a very bad eight days for the people who love the trail.'' Thurston Griggs, president of the Mountain Club of Maryland, which is responsible for the section of trail where the murders occurred, said he was pleased authorities were able to make an arrest. ``I'm disappointed it was somebody using the trail,'' Griggs said Sunday from his home in Baltimore. Noland said an extradition hearing before Jefferson County Circuit Judge Thomas Steptoe would be held within the next few days. Steptoe had an unpublished telephone number and could not be reached for comment Sunday. The two Appalachian Trail hikers were killed in their sleeping bags before dawn near Duncannon, Pa., a rural community about 10 miles north of Harrisburg. Ms. LaRue was stabbed repeatedly. Hood was shot three times. Horn, who told police he is from Loris, S.C., was arraigned Friday night and has remained in the Eastern Regional Jail in Martinsburg. ``I informed him of the charges that had been lodged aainst him and read him his rights and informed him there would be no bail,'' Noland said Sunday. ``He was very quiet and cooperative and just acknowledged his rights.'' Horn could be back in Pennsylvania in as little as a week if he does not fight extradition. Sullivan said he could not comment on whether police had any other suspects, but a state police news release Saturday said investigators had sought one individual. About 1,500 people use the trail every year. The last slaying on the trail was in 1988 near Shippensburg, Pa., about 38 miles southwest of Duncannon.

DOC.HEAD: U.S.-Born Queen of Jordan Says King Misrepresented
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: American-born Queen Noor said Sunday her husband is a loyal friend of the West, an experienced mediator for peace and an honorable man who is being misrepresented in the United States and pressured to take sides. ``There has been a lot of disinformation about his motives,'' said Queen Noor, born Lisa Halaby of Washington, D.C., in an interview. ``It has been very disturbing.'' Although King Hussein has called on Iraq to withdraw its troops from Kuwait, he has generally sided with his powerful neighbor Saddam Hussein, while still trying to promote peace negotiations. On Saturday, he appealed to the United States to withdraw its troops from Saudi Arabia as soon as possible. Queen Noor did not provide specific examples of disinformation, but her husband's reluctance to sever trade links with Iraq, mainly for economic considerations, has sparked U.S. accusations that he has become an apologist for Saddam. Since his coronation in 1953, Hussein, 54, has been one of Washington's closest Arab allies. Like their queen, a Princeton-educated daughter of a prominent airline executive, many Jordanians now feel betrayed by the United States. ``People have this attitude that you are either with us or you are against us, but this is an attitude that has never worked,'' the 39-year-old queen said in the interview at Al-Ma'awa Palace, overlooking the bustling capital. ``It has never been a responsible or constructive position in international relations. I've seen this attitude in the United States and, of course, in this region as well.'' ``The feeling is that if Jordan doesn't declare its position to be the same as that of the other country, it is against them and that it is in another camp,'' she added, not directly naming the United States. ``Jordan hasn't chosen a camp,'' she said. ``Jordan has had its role throughout history of being a crossroads, it is geographically a crossroads, and in politics it has been a mediator. It has been a force for peace and stability. Working always for that.'' On Saturday, King Hussein took his positions to the American people in a 30-minute speech broadcast on Cable News Network. He appealed to the United States to support negotiations rather than driving toward a horrible war. ``We believe that the position of Jordan could not be clearer to anyone who seeks the truth. It is based on the principles of international law, which Jordan has respected and always calls on all nations to respect,'' he said. ``Jordan is paying a terrible price for its commitment to honor, principles, justice and peace,'' he said. Like her husband, Queen Noor said the crisis clarified the need to resolve the Arab-Israeli conflict. ``It does nothing for the credibility of the West in this region to see so much emphasis placed on U.N. resolutions concerning oil producing states in the region ... and nothing like the same emphasis being placed on long-standing disputes that threaten regional peace and stability, such as the Arab-Israeli dispute. ``There are resolutions concerning that dispute that have existed for 23 years and have not been implemented,'' she said. Arabs, Queen Noor said, consider the U.S. refusal to negotiate the Israeli occupation of Palestinian territories inconsistent and unjust. ``Injustice strikes at the heart of people, at their most intense passions,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Bob Hope Says He May Entertain the Troops
DOC.TEXT: TOPEKA, Kan. (A) - Bob Hope says he might travel to Saudi Arabia to entertain U.S. forces facing Iraqi troops, but he is worried about taking beautiful women as he has on previous overseas tours. ``The Saudi Arabians, they don't like a girl unless she's wearing a veil,'' he said Saturday. ``I can't see Madonna wearing a veil.'' If he does go, he said, it would be during the Christmas holidays. Hope said he would not take his golf clubs. ``I don't need a sand trap that big,'' he said. Hope also reminisced about former President Dwight Eisenhower during his performance Saturday night at the Kansas Expocentre. The comedian met Eisenhower, then allied commander, during World War II. He was called to Eisenhower's office in Algiers while preparing a 1943 radio show. Eisenhower promised him he wouldn't experience any bombings, but the city was bombed that night for the first time in years. ``That's always been a big joke because I wired him and said, `Thanks for the rest,' '' Hope said. More than 4,000 people attended the show to benefit Ronald McDonald House, which provides low-cost shelter to families of hospitalized children. Concert promoter Doug Holladay said Hope cut his fee in half to $37,500.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Says `Host' of Options Remain Before Any War With Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III played down the possibility of war in the Persian Gulf on Sunday, saying the United States and its allies still have a ``whole host'' of non-military options to use against Iraq. But Baker said the Bush administration would unleash an ``appropriate response'' to any Iraqi-inspired acts of terrorism against American citizens. President Bush made similar comments Friday and has accused Iraq of supporting terrorist groups. Baker, appearing on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press'' program, also said the administration likely will present to Congress the first phase of its proposed weapons package for Saudi Arabia early next week. Administration sources have said the initial deal is expected to have a value of $10 billion, but Baker refused to put a price tag on it. There have been reports that the total deal was worth roughly $21 billion, a figure Baker would not confirm. Baker said the first installment of Saudi weapons deal represents ``the needs that we think are immediate for Saudi Arabia and, frankly, needs that would - that will serve to protect American lives.'' The Pentagon and the State Department were putting the final touches on the first phase of the military shopping list for the Saudis over the weekend, officials said. The package is likely to include Tow anti-tank missiles, Patriot anti-aircraft systems and F-15 fighter jets, according to sources familiar with the deal. The second installment will not be presented to Congress for approval until early 1991, Baker said. Despite the 150,000 U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia and the billions of dollars of materiel in the desert kingdom, Baker said the United States remains committed to working with the United Nations for a peaceful, diplomatic resolution. Asked if he is confident war can be avoided, Baker said: ``We have said many times we hoped there won't be.'' Bush, however, ``will not rule, and indeed should not, rule out other options,'' he said. Baker refused to discuss a report in Sunday's Washington Post that said the Defense Department had contingency plans for ground assaults against Iraq from as many as four directions. The troops might have to cross Jordan and Turkey, the report said. Saying he would not talk about any possible operations, Baker added that as long as military action remains an option ``you're going to see speculative pieces from time to time like this.'' Baker said the U.N. had a ``whole host'' of other things that might be considered in an attempt to force Iraq to withdraw its troops from Kuwait and restore that country's government. He reiterated those conditions must be met before there would be talk of negotiating with Iraq. ``I don't think we are running out of non-military type sanctions,'' Baker said. Baker's measured tone on Iraq contrasted with a bellicose statement from Baghdad on Sunday threatening to destroy oil fields in the Middle East and move against Israel if the Iraqi people are ``strangled'' by foreign forces in the Persian Gulf. The statement was issued in the name of the Revolution Command Council, the country's highest decision-making body. Baker said the United States was committed to backing the U.N. resolutions imposing trade embargoes against Iraq, Baker said. The secretary of state will join other foreign ministers this week at a U.N. Security Council meeting in New York. One of items on the agenda is imposing an air embargo against Iraq to tighten the stranglehold on Baghdad. Another possible sanction is to punish countries that break the embargo. U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said Sunday that it's likely that an air embargo will be adopted by the United Nations in the next few days. The administration agreed to the phased sale of weapons to Saudi Arabia after some members of Congress, particularly those with close ties to Israel, objected to the massive flow of weapons to the Saudis. Baker insisted the administration had not caved in to Congress, although the idea of a two-step process originated on Capitol Hill. Fred Dutton, a representative of the Saudi government, said the Saudis were not upset about the two-part sale. ``After the smoke clears they will see what their defense requirements are,'' Dutton said in a telephone interview. If the United States refuses to sell weapons to the Saudis, they will do their shopping elsewhere, he said. Baker also defended the administration's actions prior to Saddam's invasion of Kuwait. He reiterated that the United States followed the proper course in refusing to take sides in the Iraq-Kuwait border dispute, and said it was ``ludicrous'' to suggest that ``somehow the United States contributed to Saddam Hussein's unprovoked aggression'' against Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: First Full Service in Kremlin Cathedral Since 1918
DOC.TEXT: Patriarch Alexi II, head of the Russian Orthodox Church, led a Divine Liturgy in the Kremlin's Uspensky Cathedral on Sunday, the first full service allowed in more than 70 years in Russia's most important cathedral. Before the 1917 revolution, the 15th century church was the most sacred in the country. Under its five golden onion-shaped domes, czars were crowned, patriarchs were buried and conquered princes swore allegiance to Russia. Since 1918, however, it has been a museum and closed to ordinary worship. The government's decision to allow the Sunday service was an important symbolic step in the revival of the Orthodox Church, long repressed by the Communist Party because of ideological opposition to religion. About 1,000 people were allowed into the Kremlin, the walled fortress that is the seat of the Soviet government, for the service. Among them were Moscow mayor Gavriil Popov and the chairman of the national legislature, Anatoly Lukyanov. Afterward, thousands of people lined the streets as Alexi and other church leaders led a procession from the Kremlin's Trinity Gate through downtown Moscow to another historic site, the Church of the Great Ascension. ``Churches are revived not by external restoration, but by prayers said inside them,'' Alexi told the crowd outside. ``I hope you will agree with me that today's Divine Liturgy in the Uspensky Ctahedral meant more to its spiritual revival than decades of external maintenance.'' More than 30 clergymen in golden brocade robes, many carrying icons, took part in the hourlong procession. They were followed by hundreds of worshipers. People watched from balconies and windows and were packed four deep on both sides of the 2{-mile route. The crowd was quiet and respectful, and some spectators crossed themselves as the icons - paintings of the Virgin and various saints - passed by. ``We are Russians. God is with us,'' said a banner in old Russian script carried by some of the marchers. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has shown much more tolerance than previous leaders for worshipers, and has called on them to support his reform policies. Three years ago, Gorbachev met in the Kremlin with Alexi's predecessor, Pimen. It was the first meeting between leaders of the Communist Party and the Russian Orthodox Church in more than 40 years. Since then, numerous churches across the Soviet Union have been returned to the Orthodox Church and restored for worship. In prior decades, some were maintained as cultural museums, but many were allowed to fall into disrepair and were used as storehouses or offices. Since the Bolshevik Revolution, brief prayer services have been allowed in the Uspensky Cathedral on a few occasions, such as in 1988 for the 1,000th anniversary of the introduction of Christianity to Russia. But Sunday's service, which was closed to the press, was the first full one there since 1918, according to the newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda. Officially, the occasion for the service was a local holiday, the Days of Moscow, which celebrates the beauty of the capital. There are three other major churches within the Kremlin where services have been held on rare occasions. All are considered museums, but there has been speculation that one or more may soon be opened for weekly services. ``There has been talk for a long time about returning the Kremlin churches to use as cathedrals,'' Komsomolskaya Pravda wrote. ``Maybe the service on the city's holiday is one more step on the path that leads to the church.''

DOC.HEAD: Washington Post Defends Reporter Arrested While Working on Story
DOC.TEXT: The managing editor of The Washington Post says a staff reporter broke no law when he was arrested for allegedly contributing to the delinquency of a minor while working on a story for the newspaper and called the police action ``unwarranted.'' ``Based on the information we have, the arrest of a Washington Post reporter while he is reporting a story and breaking no law himself appears unwarranted to us,'' said Leonard Downie, Jr., Managing Editor of the Post. ``I'm particularly concerned that the police pursued this after the reporter identified himself and his purpose and that the police took his notes,'' Downie said. Michael J. Ybarra, 23, a reporter with the Post's Metro staff was arrested late Friday while working on a report about a new curfew for minors in Quantico, Va. Ybarra's supervisors said the reporter was not available for comment concerning the incident. Ybarra was taken into custody and his notes confiscated while conducting an interview of two 12-year-old boys in a restaurant in the Virgina town about 30 miles south of the nation's capital. The Quantico Town Council recently imposed a 10 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew for youths under age 18 following recent vandalism in the area. Ybarra is the second adult charged in connection with a curfew violation, but no youths have been arrested. ``I believe that the reporter was trying to do his job and just got mixed up at the wrong place and the wrong time,'' said Leo Rodriguez, Quantico Police Chief. Rodriguez said the reporter's notes were held as evidence but a copy would be made available to the Post. Ybarra, who was released on his own recognizance, is to be arraigned in Prince William County Juvenile and Domestic Relations Court on Tuesday. He faces a maximum one year in jail and a fine of $2,500 fine.

DOC.HEAD: Not Enough Nuts at Oregon's State Capitol
DOC.TEXT: Political pundits might tell you there are more than enough nuts at the state Capitol, but Jim Archambault is looking for a few more. Archambault, the state's landscape manager, needs them soon so the squirrels won't go hungry this winter. Some 40 to 100 gray squirrels live in the Capitol Mall area, and in the winter months they have to rely on handouts. Archambault, who strolled through the area Friday with a handful of acorns, said state officials gladly accept donations on behalf of the squirrels. The animals are partial to filberts and English walnuts, but will also eat peanuts, he said. Harold Shahan of Salem, who was feeding the squirrels some peanuts on his own Friday, said he has discovered they also like M&M peanu candies. ``But you have to stay with the same color or they get confused,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Britain, Hong Kong Say Vietnam Move on Refugees Important Step
DOC.TEXT: Britain and Hong Kong on Sunday welcomed Vietnam's decision to take back boat people who are not opposed to returning home from Hong Kong camps. The official Vietnam News Agency said the agreement was reached in talks in Hanoi last week by British and Hong Kong officials and representatives of the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees. The brief report, dated Saturday and seen in Bangkok on Sunday, did not say if the agreement applied to the tens of thousands of boat people stuck in camps in Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia and other Asian countries. Under the terms of the July 1989 Geneva conference, all boat people are screened in order to determine which refugees are eligible for resettlement in the West. Those who fled to escape political persecution are eligible; those who left for economic reasons are not. The new agreement is seen as a compromise that stops short of forced repatriation. Fifty-one Vietnamese were repatriated against their will in December, bt no others have been forced back because of objections from the United States and Vietnam. Hong Kong and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations - Thailand, Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines and Brunei - continued pressuring Vietnam and threatened to turn back Vietnamese boats unless the United States eased its stand. In late July, Secretary of States James A. Baker III told Southeast Asian nations that the United States continued to oppose forced repatriation but could accept the new category of ``those who do not object.'' In London, a Foreign Office official said the agreements reached in Hanoi were an ``important step.'' `Our objective remains the repatriation of all screened-out boat people to Vietnam,'' the official said. ``We will be cooperating fully with the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees in the implementation of agreements.'' In Hong Kong, the governor, Sir David Wilson, also described the agreement as an important step to accelerate the return of non-refugees to Vietnam. Wilson told reporters he hopes the repatriation program will begin before the end of this year, adding: ``You cannot have people who are non-refugees spending year after year in camps. That is simply not right.'' So far, 4,349 Vietnamese boat people have returned from Hong Kong under a voluntary repatriation program that began in March 1989 with support from the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees. About 54,000 boat people remain in Hong Kong camps. About 9,000 are classified as refugees and will be resettled in the West. The other 45,000 are either waiting to be screened for determination of their status, or have been classified as non-refugees for repatriation. Since June 1988, when Hong Kong stopped automatically allowing boat people to stay, 49,466 have arrived there - 4,916 of them this year.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem and Military: Faith, Jobs Collide for Two Robins Sergeants
DOC.TEXT: Two Moslem members of the U.S. military often think about having to go to battle in the region that holds what they consider the holiest place in the world. Meekail Shaheed, 26, and Abdullah Shamsid-Deen, 38, are both Air Force sergeants and practicing Moslems. The two men express concern for fellow members of the military who also are members of the Sunni Islamic faith. They say they are a little wary of the huge foreign military force that is inside Saudi Arabia, site of Islam's holiest place - the city of Mecca. ``Any time you get forces close to any kind of holy land, religious people are going to be concerned,'' Shaheed said. But both say they would have no reservations about serving in the multinational force there. ``Not at all,'' said Shamsid-Deen, a 13-year military man who converted to Islam 17 years ago. ``I believe we would be being going over there in the name of right. We would not be going over there to destroy something, but to protect and defend.'' At Robins, both men perform administrative duties in the base chapel. Their jobs allow them time to carry out their Islamic duties, which include five daily prayers and yearly fasts during the month of Ramadan. ``The chaplains are out front in respecting and protecting the freedom of all religions here on base,'' said Shamsid-Deen. ``I would hope that Moslems in other areas would have the same protection and freedom.'' Both men say they are encouraged by changing public attitudes toward their religion, partly because of events in the Middle East. ``People seem to be more supportive of Islam now,'' said Shamsid-Deen, noting that several Islamic countries are allied with Western forces against Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Still, the two men watch events in the Middle East with trepidation. One of the five pillars of Islam is for a Moslem to visit Mecca at least once in one's life. Shamsid-Deen made the pilgrimage in 1979, but Shaheed has not yet had the opportunity. ``We all hope this can be taken care of as quickly as possible,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Colonial Role Drives Resentment of Bases
DOC.TEXT: Students and national leaders rail against the American military presence in the Philippines despite opinion surveys that show sizable public support for the U.S. bases. No prominent politician unequivocally supports the bases, which U.S. officials claim pump $1 billion a year into the economy and provide 100,000 jobs in a nation facing political instability and a possible recession. The Philippines has much to gain from the presence of U.S. bases, but the opposition to them illustrates how much some Filipinos fear continued influence by their old colonial rulers. ``You must understand that other Asian peoples, the Singaporeans, and Japanese and the Koreans, can deal easier with the Americans because you were never their colonial master,'' said one Asian diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``For the Filipinos, it's different.'' he said. ``The old relationship of ruler and the ruled is a heavy psychological burden.'' Angry students last week backed a pullout, chanting ``U.S. bases out!'' in demonstrations near the U.S. Embassy. American officials warned of bombings and assassinations by anti-bases extremists. During four days of talks on the bases last week, no Filipino politician of national status expressed complete support for retaining them after their lease expires in September 1991. The talks adjourned Friday and were expected to resume in about a month. President Corazon Aquino said the United States and the Philippines should discuss the ``orderly withdrawal'' of the 40,000 U.S. troops, Defense Department civilians and military dependents at Clark Air Base, the Subic Bay naval base and four smaller facilities. Mrs. Aquino said Sunday in her weekly radio broadcast that she felt confident ``our two countries shall arrive at an understanding that will be mutually acceptable and mutually beneficial.'' Anti-bases sentiment is strongest in the educated urban middle class that produces university professors, journalists and other opinion-makers. Activists are convinced that building opposition to the bases is simply a matter of educating their ``uninformed'' countrymen. A survey in March by the Ateneo University found that 35 percent of the 1,200 Filipinos polled nationwide were unaware that the United States maintains bases here. Only 18 percent wanted the bases either phased out or closed immediately. Forty percent supported keeping them indefinitely. Closing the bases represents an assertion of sovereignty against the United States, which many Filipinos believe still exerts powerful influence over their country more than 40 years after independence. Over the years, Filipino ``nationalism'' has come to be defined as standing up to America and its most visible symbol - the bases. Support for the bases would brand a politician as ``anti-nationalist,'' an unpatriotic tool of the former colonial power. Many Filipinos believe the United States interferes in Philippine affairs to guarantee keeping the bases. That view was reinforced by Washington's longtime support for the late President Ferdinand Marcos. Despite alleged U.S. sponsorship of ``democracy,'' the Americans tolerated Marcos' repressive rule, apparently to maintain their bases. Opposition to Marcos, therefore, took on the added character of opposition to the bases. Many of those in the forefront of the anti-Marcos struggle now hold key positions in the administration, the congress and the media. The bases have become so symbolic of American ``intervention'' that any U.S. move is seen as a bid to retain the installations. In December, U.S. jets flew air cover for pro-Aquino forces against military mutineers seeking to topple her. That was widely interpreted as a bid to pressure her into keeping the bases. During a devastating earthquake in July, U.S. troops rushed to stricken cities to help in relief operations. Residents of the quake-stricken city of Cabanatuan joked that the bases would remain forever because the government simply could not function without them. ``The current talks between the Philippines and the United States should usher in a new relationship between the two countries,'' said Rev. Joaquin Bernas, president of Ateneo University. ``For the Philippines, it should be a major step in the direction of greater self-reliance and not continuing dependency,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Critics Acclaim Rushdie's First Book Since ``The Satanic Verses''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1 graf for 4th graf, `The late...' to delete word `first.' Pick up 5th graf, `The new...'
DOC.TEXT: Salman Rushdie's first book since Iran called for his death is a fairy tale for children, acclaimed by critics Sunday as a charming and lighthearted work with a serious message for adults as well. Reviewers marveled that Rushdie could write with such mischievous humor despite 19 months in hiding under police guard, during which he has moved constantly and become separated from his wife, the American novelist Marianne Wiggins. Most critics, however, also saw signs of pain and desperation in the prose of ``Haroun and The Sea of Stories.'' The late Ayatolah Ruhollah Khomeini called for Rushdie's death after the author's novel ``The Satanic Verses,'' was deemed blasphemous to Islam. The new book tells the tale of a Hindu storyteller whose talent is suddenly destroyed by a fanatical dictator who poisons the springs of his inspiration. His brave son, Haroun, eventually defeats the enemy of stories and restores his father's gift. Rushdie dedicates the book to his own son with these lines: ``As I wander far from view Read, and bring me home to you.'' British writer Anthony Burgess, reviewing the book in the Observer newspaper, said the dedication ``renews rage'' at ``the stupidity of the Islamic deathmongers, burning a book they do not have the intelligence to understand.'' Burgess called it a ``great tribute to the resilience of Mr. Rushdie's beleaguered spirit that he should write so charmingly funny a book.'' ``It is a book to enjoy and not to explicate but, if we wish, we can take it as a piece of Swiftian outrage at human folly disguised as a children's tale,'' Burgess wrote. Rushdie, a British citizen born into a Moslem family in India, was sentenced to death Feb. 14, 1989. Even after Khomeini's death last year, the sentence was not lifted by Iranian leaders. Rushdie has since published poetry and several essays and reviews, but ``Haroun and The Sea of Stories'' is his first book since he went into hiding. It will be published by Granta Books in Britain Sept. 27 and in the United States next year. Graham Lord, literary editor of The Sunday Express, said Rushdie ``has managed during his awful captivity to write a remarkably lighthearted, almost mischievous children's book.'' But Lord found ``poignant autobiographical shadows of Rushdie's own dreadful predicament,'' especially in the remark of one character who said: ``Happy endings are much rarer in stories, and also in life, than most people think.'' ``Coming from Rushdie, in apparently unending captivity, that sounds like a desperate cry echoing in the dark,'' Lord said. David Hughes, in The Mail on Sunday, said: ``Salman Rushdie, the flags of merriment flying throughout his allegory, wins a grim fight of his own ... His fine book, written in conditions in which such ebullience of mood takes courage, is a great re-echoing cry for freedom of word and view, for the inarguable truth in a good story.'' Writer and critic Marina Warner, reviewing the book in The Sunday Times, which published several excerpts, said Rushdie's ``jauntiness'' under sentence of death ``is matter for wonder enough'' but ``what is even more so is the ... absolutely unpompous treatment of the villains in the story.'' Rushdie ``meditates on compromise, on the sympathy of opposites, the symbolic beauty of silence and the night as well as their terrors,'' she wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Rain In Southwest And Northeast
DOC.TEXT: Rain was scattered over the Southwest on Sunday, with locally heavy rain causing minor flooding, and rain also was scattered across the northeastern quarter of the nation. Afternoon showers and thunderstorms extended over east-central through southeastern Nevada and northwestern Arizona, extending into parts of California, and over parts of New Mexico and the southwest half of Texas. Several rural roads in Texas' Val Verde County were closed by high water, the National Weather Service said. Flood warnings were posted along the Rio Grande from Presidio, Texas, through Big Bend National Park to the mouth of the Pecos River below Langtry, Texas. The river crested at Lajitas at nearly 5 feet above flood stage, the weather service said. Showers and thunderstorms also were scattered over eastern Upper Michigan, northeastern Lower Michigan, Ohio, New York state, Pennsylvania, northern West Virginia, eastern Virginia, Delaware, eastern Maryland, and northern Maine. Warnings of gale force wind were posted over Lake Erie, Lake Huron and western Lake Ontario. Elsewhere, showers and thunderstorms also spread across the Florida Peninsula. Rainfall amounts during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT were less than 1 inch. Also in Florida, West Palm Beach warmed to a record high of 93, and Key West tied its record high of 92. Sunday's low for the Lower 48 states was 25 at West Yellowstone, Mont. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 45 at Alpena and Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., to 94 at Fort Myers, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Military Equipment Still Getting Through To Iraq, Officers Say
With AM-Gulf Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Seven weeks after the United Nations imposed sanctions on Iraq, military equipment and other material with war potential continues to slip through the naval web, U.S. officers said Sunday. The officers said shipments marked for delivery to the Jordanian port of Aqaba are actually being taken overland to Iraq. The amount and type of cargo passing through Aqaba is classified information. But officers familiar with the situation indicate the flow has been fairly extensive. They say their suspicions are based partly on confidential intelligence data. One cargo vessel, intercepted by the U.S. Navy within the past week, carried British-made Land Rovers painted in military camouflage, they said. They said they could not reveal where the cargo was coming from. Another ship was carrying a load of scrap metal, aluminum, silica and other materials that are ``basic components in the manufacture of explosives,'' one officer said. In both cases, the cargoes were listed on the ships' manifests as bound for Aqaba, and there was no way for American boarding parties to determine whether they were ultimately destined for Iraq, about a 350-mile trip by road, the officers said. ``We suspect that's where some of the stuff labeled for Aqaba is going, but we don't have proof,'' said Capt. Paul Prokop, commander of U.S. Coast Guard teams taking part in the multinational effort to enforce the U.N. sanctions. ``There are a lot of ways for an innovative shipper to avoid a blockade, and as the price goes up, they become more innovative,'' he added. Jordan insists it is abiding by the embargo even though it faces economic devastation. King Hussein has called for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, but has generally sided with Baghdad since the Aug. 2 invasion. Officials in Aqaba said the port is at a near standstill because of the sanctions, with the number of arriving ships dwindling from about 25 a day to two or three. Aqaba, Jordan's only seaport, is normally a major transit point for Iraq-bound goods. The U.N. Security Council imposed an economic embargo in response to the Iraqi invasion. The council later approved the use of minimal force to prevent ships from trading with Iraq. ``The effort is far from being airtight, as any observer is well aware ... If the powers that be are going to have this effort as airtight as they want, someone's going to have to speak to our friends in Jordan,'' said Prokop. As of Sunday, officers said the U.S. Navy had conducted 1,251 interceptions of mechant ships since sanctions were imposed Aug. 6. Of these, 880 were in the Gulf of Oman, Arabian Sea and the Persian Gulf, with 371 in the Red Sea, the route for the narrow Gulf of Aqaba and the Jordanian port. But the pattern of activity is reversed when it comes to boardings. Of 105 boardings to date, 80 to 90 were in the Red Sea. Ships from about eight other navies, including the British, French, Italian and Australian, are also participating in interdiction operations. The warship crews ask all passing merchant vessels to name their ports of origin, destination and cargo. If there are suspicions a ship may be carrying cargo to or from Iraq or occupied Kuwait, it is asked to allow a boarding party to inspect the manifest and cargo. If the cargo is found to be Iraqi-related, the ship is instructed to divert to another port. There have been six such diversions so far, the officers said. In three other instances, warning shots were fired to force ships to stop and be searched. U.S. officers say their warships have the option of shooting to disable a ship tht defies challenge. So far, that has not happened.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Foreign Minister Visits U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister David Levy flew to New York Sunday to talk to U.S. officials about Middle East peace and to the Soviets about renewing diplomatic relations. Levy is expected to voice Israeli objections to a proposed U.S. arms sale to Saudi Arabia and seek more U.S. military aid for Israel, according to a newspaper quoting diplomatic sources. On Saturday, Levy is scheduled to meet his Soviet counterpart, Eduard Shevardnadze, when they attend the U.N. General Assembly. ``I expect to hear from Shevardnadze what direction Soviet policy will be taking in order to advance toward a resumption of diplomatic relations between our two countries,'' Levy said before leaving for the United States. The Soviet Union broke ties with Israel following the 1967 Middle East war. Relations have warmed under Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and the two countries exchanged diplomatic missions in 1987. Levy said his meeting with Shevardnadze was arranged last week in Moscow by an Israeli Foreign Ministry delegation. The Kremlin says it will restore full diplomatic ties if Israel agrees to an international Middle East peace conference. Israel believes a conference would force it to make concessions, and insists on negotiating directly with Arab governments. Levy is also to meet with Secretary of State James A. Baker III this week and hear about the talks Baker held in Syria and Saudi Arabia earlier this month on the Persian Gulf crisis and related issues. ``We will also be talking about and expressing ideas about the supply of such tremendous ammounts of arms to Saudi Arabia. I shall be expressing Israel's needs in my talks with Baker,'' Levy said. The Haaretz newspaper Sunday quoted diplomatic sources saying Levy will note Israel's opposition to a proposed $10 billion U.S. arms sale to Saudi Arabia, and press Israel's request for more U.S. military aid. Israel is seeking $1 billion to buy more sophisticated planes and other weapons to match the proposed Saudi deal. This is in addition to a $700 million increase in the annual $1.8 billion U.S. military aid package to Israel. Levy is also expected to meet with 15 foreign ministers at the United Nations, including those from China, Egypt, Japan and Turkey.

DOC.HEAD: President Says He Will Not Negotiate With Drug Traffickers
DOC.TEXT: President Cesar Gaviria, faced with a hostage crisis blamed on the Medellin cocaine cartel, told Colombians Sunday his government would not negotiate with drug traffickers. Gaviria's administration has tried to hush press reports about the hostages - seven journalists and the sister of a Colombian ambassador. The government has yet to acknowledge they are being held by the Medellin cartel and has forbidden radio news coverage of such ``unconfirmed reports.'' But the cartel claimed responsibility for three of the eight kidnappings over the past few weeks in a statement faxed to local news media last week. Newspapers have quoted security officials as saying the statement is authentic. And local newspapers have cited reliable cartel sources as saying all eight kidnapping victims are in the traffickers' hands. In a letter published Sunday in Bogota's El Espectador newspaper, the president addressed questions about how he is handling his first crisis since taking office on Aug. 7. A Saturday editorial had voiced the doubts of many Colombians by asking if the government was ``surreptitiously conversing with drug traffickers.'' Gaviria answered with a resounding ``No.'' ``Everything can be presumed except that the government is carrying on a dialogue or maintaining whatever type of contact with criminal organizations,'' the president said in his letter to the newspaper. The recent string of kidnappings ended a nearly two-month break in the cartel's terrorist campaign. The Medellin traffickers declared a unilateral cease-fire in the campaign last July, saying they wanted to demonstrate their desire for peace. Bombings and other attacks by the cartel had killed more than 500 people in the year before the truce was declared. Earlier this month, Gaviria offered traffickers an incentive to turn themselves in. He said traffickers who surrender would be tried in Colombia, rather than extradited to the United States. He also offered reduced prison sentences for drug suspects in exchange for their cooperation with authorities. Last week's statement by the Medellin cartel said Gaviria's offer was unacceptable. Instead, traffickers say they want a full amnesty for past crimes.

DOC.HEAD: World Changes Weaken Leverage Of Poor Countries, Leader Says
DOC.TEXT: The Middle East crisis must not be allowed to overshadow or hinder the long-term battle against world poverty, the chairman of an international financial committee said Sunday. Bernard Chidzero, chairman of the Development Committee of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, said the possibility of worldwide inflation and high interest rates triggered by Iraq's takeover of Kuwait will affect discussions of the group on Monday. But he said the world's greatest challenge is still the eradication of poverty. The Development Committee is made up of finance ministers and other officials from 22 countries who advise the bank and the fund on the transfer of resources to developing countries. One billion people either live in poverty or on the brink of poverty, said Chidzero, who is also finance minister of Zimbabwe. ``I do not believe we can build a safe and stable world when we have hundreds of millions of people'' living without shelter or dying of hunger, he said at a news conference. He criticized rich nations for expecting developing countries to open up trade barriers while they refuse to adopt more liberal policies themselves. But Chidzero said it is becoming more difficult for poor nations to maintain a unified voice in trade negotiations, since some are more successful than others at achieving growth. He said that although newly emerging democracies in Eastern Europe have some similarity with the developing countries of the world, their history, location and racial ties to developed countries give them an advantage in pushing towards development.

DOC.HEAD: Right-Wing Leader Says Iraq Embargo `Unworthy of Civilized Nations'
DOC.TEXT: The leader of the right-wing National Front party said Sunday the trade embargo against Iraq was beneath the international community and warned the Persian Gulf crisis could spur new waves of immigration. ``It is unworthy of civilized nations to want to starve the Iraqi population, just as it is unworthy to want to destroy it by bombings,'' Jean-Marie Le Pen told several thousand followers at the close of the party's annual festival. Le Pen has been often criticized for alleged anti-Semitic remarks and his strong stance against immigrants, particularly those from Arab nations. Since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, Le Pen's comments against Western intervention led to some defections from his party, which holds one seat in the 577-member National Assembly. Le Pen said the gulf crisis would lead to increased immigration, unemployment and other economic problems in France. ``It is not Iraq which is responsible for the rising price of oil,'' Le Pen said. ``The responsibility lies with the blockade organized by Western nations.'' The U.N. Security Council on Aug. 6 approved the trade embargo, which is being enforced by ships from the United States, France and other nations. Le Pen, a member of the European Parliament, also blamed the French government for threats to French citizens trapped in Kuwait and Iraq. He claimed the world's major powers knew Iraq was planning to invade Kuwait. ``So it was with full knowledge that the French government left French citizens behind'' as hostages, he said. Paris Mayor Jacques Chirac was criticized for allowing the National Front party festival to convene in a section of the Bois de Boulogne park on the western edge of Paris. More than six towns have banned National Front gatherings since the May 10 desecration of a Jewish cemetery in Carpentras in southern France. Authorities accused Le Pen of indirect responsibility. The Natonal Front, formed in 1984, has the support of about 15 percent of French voters, according to polls earlier this year.

DOC.HEAD: Recovery of Italian Painting in Paris Leads to Other Stolen Works
DOC.TEXT: The recovery of a 15th century portrait and the capture of the man who allegedly stole it from an Italian museum led police to a cache of six other paintings snatched from museums in Paris over the summer. Police raided an apartment Saturday in a posh Paris neighborhood and found the portrait of the doge Francesco Foscari, stolen Friday from the Correr Museum in Saint Mark's Square in Venice. The suspect, Richard Etoh-Mvondo, 21, provided information that led police to six stolen paintings that were being kept in Lyon, in southeast France, authorities said Sunday. The paintings, including a Renoir stolen from the Louvre, were lifted from their frames during visiting hours at various Paris museums. Police did not say whether they believed Etoh-Mvondo was involved in those thefts. They gave no indication of whether there were other suspects. The 20- by 16-inch portrait of Francesco Foscari, painted about 1470 by Lazzaro Bastiani, was removed from its frame in the second-floor gallery of the city-run Correr Museum in Venice. Venetian police contacted French authorities after a security guard at the museum reported noticing a suspicious French-speaking man near the stolen work. The thief apparently concealed the painting in pastry-wrapping paper and took it by train to Paris. It was not damaged, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Romania Seeks Development of Private Enterprise, Joins IFC
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Theodor is cq in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: Romania became the 138th member of the World Finance Corp. on Sunday, signaling a quest for private enterprise in a formerly communist-ruled country where all major businesses still are run by the state. ``It's a big step in our economic program for the transition to a market economy,'' said Romanian Finance Minister Theodor Stolojan. The IFC, which is affiliated with the World Bank, finances and assists in the development of private enterprise in developing countries. Stolojan, in Washington for the World Bank and International Monetary Fund annual meetings, said his country previously had no reason to join the IFC ``because there was no room for the private sector.'' Earlier this year, the Romanian parliament agreed to grant 30 percent of state-owned corporations to the public, with a voucher system that would distribute shares to each adult citizen. The remaining 70 percent would be sold in shares to Romanian and foreign investors, Stolojan said. The first challenge for the international agency, he said, will be to help Romania develop a stock market. There is also great potential for a tourist industry, he said. ``We are firm in our decision to go to a market economy,'' the finance minister said at a joint news conference with IFC director Douglas Gustafson who said a team would be sent to Romania to see how the country can be helped in its efforts to develop more private enterprise. Gustafson said it was too early to predict how much financing would be needed. He said the organization would start by providing technical assistance. The IFC, he said, could help create private sector activity, financial markets and joint ventures. Mugur Isarescu, governor of the National Bank of Romania, said the country also plans to develop a full-fledged central bank and a private banking system but needs more skilled personnel. Isarescu said there would be difficulties changing from the ``command economy'' developed under 45 years of Communist rule, which ended with free elections in May following the December 1989 overthrow of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. ``I don't think it is possible to just say `bing-bang' and have a market economy,'' Isarescu said. The Romanian officials said signs of progress are already apparent in the country, with more than 4,000 small enterprises operating and thousands more ``inside-the-family businesses.'' Last Easter, Stolojan said, Romanians for the first Easter in 20 years could buy eggs in the market because of the development of agricultural businesses on unused land deeded to individuals by the state.

DOC.HEAD: Raccoons Who Raid Human Food Face Similar Health Problems
DOC.TEXT: Raccoons who snack on Twinkies, Oreos and Big Macs suffer the same consequences as humans - rotten teeth and high cholesterol, researchers say. Scientists say they were shocked by results from a small sampling of the masked mischief-makers that roam Illinois parks and campgrounds, scavenging human food. ``Their mouths look like those pictures in the dentist's office that show what will happen if you don't brush,'' said Laura Hungerford, a University of Illinois veterinarian. ``I think they have a lot of sugar in their diet.'' Wild raccoons usually have healthy teeth, but Hungerford found broken teeth, gum disease and cavities in the campground animals. Many park raccoons also had cuts on their faces and paws; a few suffered broken legs. ``Raccoons are aggressive for food,'' Hungerford said. ``The injuries probably are related to digging through trash cans or getting hit by swinging garbage can lids.'' In the wild, raccoons eat berries, grass, small fish and rodents - they're not particular. Researchers don't know specifically what kinds of human food the racoons are eating because they're not choosy. ``They're omnivores (that) will eat anything from bugs to pizza,'' said Charles Nixon, a wildlife biologist at the Illinois Natural History Survey, which is cooperating in the study with the University of Illinois and Western Illinois University. The early findings from a survey this spring prompted a more thorough investigation, now underway, of how raccoons interact with people. Researchers will trap and examine 100 raccoons this fall, half in Siloam Springs State Park in western Illinois and half in the wilds of Brown County. After about 12 hours, they will be returned to the wild. In addition to mouth and body examinations, the raccoons' blood will be tested for any diseases that could be shared with humans. The researchers, who are examining whether racoons may transfer diseases to humans or vice versa, have already have found that some snacking raccoons suffer high cholesterol levels. ``This is important because humans are using recreational areas more and more, bringing humans and raccoons into more intimate contact,'' Hungerford said. Park officials already have modified many trash containers so raccoons cannot get into them easily and aren't as likely to be injured trying, but the animals have learned that people bring food. ``During the weekend when there are fewer visitors, there are fewer raccoons, and they concentrate around the campsites that are being used,'' Hungerfor said. Some of the animals will be tagged with radio collars to see how far they roam and where they take shelter. Capture is not difficult, using box-type traps that do not hurt the raccoons. They're lured into the traps by smelly bait like sardines and mustard sauce. ``A couple of these coons have decided they like being trapped - you get food,'' Hungerford said.
